review_title: Heart of West Michigan United Way
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Most coworkers believe in the vision/mission and are passionate about helping people. Decent PTO and hybrid work flexible (but doesn't make up for poor pay and benefits).
cons: There are many managers here who are creating an extremely toxic environment. Turnover is very high and leadership dismisses genuine concerns as mere complaints from disgruntled employees. When someone leaves the organization, things get so much worse because they don't address existing problems, hire inexperienced people for crucial roles, and often don't fill needed positions, instead choosing to reallocate work to employees who are already burnt out, under valued, and under paid. As much as they focus on helping working families/individuals that still can't afford to make ends meet, the shockingly low compensation causes many of their employees to suffer the same struggles. The declining reputation Heart of West Michigan United Way has in the community reflects the abundance of issues surrounding both their culture and fundraising model.

pros: NONE - unless you count "flexing your work hours"

Upper management gets all the money while their employees suffer from HORRIBLE work hours and uncommunicated expectations.
They let you flex your hours but you and your team end up working over 60 hours a week because of the horrible lack of leaderships.
Tasks or deadlines usually get communicated the day off at 4 PM and is expected to be done that moment (was not just a one time thing, this was DAILY). 
Upper management KNOWS nothing and basically just guess what donors/people want and from there it takes at least 5 different tries before you can get any clear communication to get things done correctly.
After calculating salary to hours worked, my team was basically working less than minimum wages and when asked for fair compensation, it is never within budgets but yet the CEO and all the others are making will over $200k-$500k. 
There is literally no room to grow with leadership that keep "offering their help" and then stack more work onto your plate and never compensate you for your hours.
Unless you are White and are working in the Office of Development, do not expect any kind of fair pay at all. 
They truly take advantage of kind people wanting to make a difference in the community.

review_title: Should Have Filed a Disability Discrimination Lawsuit
pros: Remote work from home options.
cons: I should have filed a disability discrimination lawsuit against UWSEM, but didn't have the means to do so at the time. Instances of discrimination are too numerous to mention here. For example, my supervisor openly stated that me being in a wheelchair made other co-workers uncomfortable. I was bullied and harassed on a daily basis, despite receiving high performance reviews. HR intervened and created a new role for me that had zero substance to remove me from the abusive department I was in. I was later laid off because the new role that they created had no real responsibilities. In essence, I was illegally fired due to being disabled - they just found a very creative way to accomplish that. I had a strong case for suing them, but ultimately chose not to since they are a non-profit and I didn't want to harm the organizations they fund and support. That said, I would highly advise that you don't choose to work here. It is a highly toxic workplace for able bodied individuals as well. There is no work-life balance and the turnover rate is incredibly high.

pros: Perhaps the biggest pro of working at United Way are the benefits, particularly their insurance coverage benefits; the costs are covered in full by the organization. Their 403 (b) plan and vacation pay are about average compared to other firms in the region. There are remote work options. Most time is spent in office, however, remote work is available if needed. The organization is flexible. The employees are exceptionally nice. Very respectful, well-intentioned, and commendable people.
cons: The biggest con of working at United Way is meeting demand of stakeholders and management with less than ideal tools. The organization seems underequipped at times with the expectations of the organization unabated. The organization experiences a high degree of turnover; be prepared to fill in for another position. Management does not communicate the breadth of the job during the hiring process. Over my employment, approximately 5% of my time was doing my hired job role. The other 95% was spent filling in for another employee and various other tasks that required a high degree of involvement. Many of which are consistent year to year according to other employees and are not mentioned during the hiring process. While the expectations of me as a person and professional are clear, the expectations of how to accomplish a given task are exceptionally unclear. This arises due to lack of skills, minimal training, and inadequate instruction. Management attempts to train and guide employees quite literally through a spreadsheet called a work plan. To highlight this lack of clarity, I once asked a fairly intricate question, and rather than answer the question, the response was to "read the workplan." Management seemingly wants to absolve themselves of instructing their inferiors, to their own detriment at times. Expectations suddenly become clear when the result was not exactly what they wanted.

pros: Connecting to important work and incredible clients.

pros:
Can be a good place to move up quickly…but only if you have a really hard work ethic, are willing to put in long hours, are ready to wear multiple hats and take on additional responsibilities without complaints or expectations of immediate reward

Workplace renovation completes in April 

Ability to make a difference in the community

Benefits aren’t great, but pay can be competitive compared to other local nonprofits
cons:
Work/life balance. If you are a 9-5 person with strong boundaries or want remote work options, move on. You can stay late and work extra all the time with no pushback, but if you show up late a few times and it’s noticed, expect comments. Leadership has different rules for themselves.

Culture. There are real culture challenges that leadership is trying to address, but it’s been a long time coming and won’t be resolved anytime soon. Old school ways of thinking about culture and flexibility (or lack thereof). Lots of politics and in-crowds. Some great people will never move up because they keep to themselves while some people get promoted continuously.

Leadership. CEO and VPs don’t listen to staff. They pick favorites and make a lot of decisions without asking for input. Some VPs are lacking in basic leadership and office professionalism.

Holiday schedule is really lacking.

You’ll never get compensated for working overtime, but you’ll always get vacation time deducted in full (even if you worked extra other days).

cons:
Conservative:

job_title: Client Service Representative Care4Kids in Rocky Hill, CT
pros: Great Benefits, time off and great health insurance coverage plans. Work parties, and they occasionally have pizza parties, ice cream, potlucks. very flexible dress code.
cons: Pay  is not much to live off of if you live independently and  for the type of situations you deal with on a daily basis. My advice is if you are an empathetic  individual, The Care4Kids  CSR job is not for you. You will become so emotionally invested in cases, and Management cares more about the amount of calls you take and how quick you go from one call to another. Im not kidding, you will do well here if you can manage  getting through calls quickly without letting them affect you emotionally. You are allowed a small amount of empathy as long as you can finish the call and wrap it up within 6 minutes. because you are working with clients that need childcare assistance, so a lot of these parents are dealing with really tough situations. and it can be hard to put you metrics over helping them. In this job you have to remember that you are A call center rep not a case manager or an investigator so whatever problems you face on the phone with the caller, you cannot take on their problems, for the sake of your metrics ( performance measurement) and job performance. I only hate that because I enjoy helping people even if it means stepping outside of my position :(

review_title: Not transparent. Lies to employees for their own benefit.
pros: 15 years ago it was great. So much fun to work there. Their best asset is the staff - not the management. Management are all phony.

They were creating a new position at a higher, management level that was analytical so this was their excuse to get rid of me because they had nothing to fire me for. They did get a new position filled but not until 2 months later and that was with an internal person who was already there. One week after I left on my own and got a great job elsewhere, they posted my same exact job at a lower salary level. They clearly want younger people who will work for less money. I busted my butt working day and night to keep up with the tasks they put on me. I didn’t ask for extra pay, as I was hourly but I just wanted to keep my job and do my best. Staff looked to me for advice and we all got along great. Management are totally phony. They promote their favorites even if they do nothing extra to deserve it. Management keeps getting promoted themselves and take credit for the work that the staff does with barely a thank you.

pros: Benefits, learning experience and personal growth. The benefits at UW are amazing. The first year you have three weeks vacation and 12 personal days. Not to mention there were time we would get extra days off. Depending on if we reached our campaign goal in December. We would receive an extra week off between Christ,as and new years. The insurance was nothing. I do not have a family and I received full coverage for no money at all. For families it was 25.00 a paycheck I think. Could be possibly less. I paid 0.67 a month for dental! I also learned a lot from upper management there. They want to see you succeed and help teach you as much as possible to make sure your doing your job correctly and learning.
cons: Pay. Its a non-profit whihc pays decent but in the larger cities where the cost of living is higher it equals out to being not all that great. I would have to say that might be one of the only downsides I saw. Sometimes you are over worked but I honestly didnt think it was that bad. We all have to make sacrifices, especially in a non-profit enviornment. Development especially because you are always networking. At the United Way in Miami Im pretty sure they did not let the hourly employees receive overtime as well. Although I think some of them worked over time on occasions. That was their choice though.

review_title: United Way Worldwide - lots of promise but a little crazy to work there
pros: Mission, opportunity, scale, great people, heart in the right place, tons of potential, brand, position in the sector, relationship with corporate partners.
cons: There are 1,800 local United Ways with their own CEOs and Boards vs. UWW which is not a headquarters but is instead something between a member service hub and a leadership organization for the network.  It also happens to have one of the lowest membership fees of any similar non-profit, i.e. UWW has a very thin budget compared to American Red Cross, Catholic Charities, etc.  Between the skimpy budget and the conflicting roles of member service vs. network leadership, UWW has a bit of a split personality.  This results in elusive priorities, high turnover, institutional knowledge that keeps having to rebuild, multiple re-organizations over the years, and a set of fits and starts for implementing strategies that can move the network.  They made a good move in 2016 by bringing in a Chief Culture Officer and that could help them. There's a ton of promise for UWW and the UW network but they've got to bring that promise to the forefront.  I wish them the best!

review_title: Making a difference, inside and out
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: This is an organization that tries really hard to walk its talk. While no company can get it right all the time, it is impressive to see how much effort the CEO puts into communicating--even the hard news--and into listening. The work itself is rewarding and seeing the impact of UWBA's efforts to cut poverty in the San Francisco Bay Area is really gratifying. It makes coming to work easy. Lots of organizations talk about being transparent and committed to diversity. Few do as much to achieve both. The benefits, the work/life balance, and the salaries are good by nonprofit standards. Telecommuting and alternative schedule options are a plus.
cons: The United Way system as a whole is facing challenges. The workplace campaign, so long a main stay of its impressive fundraising achievements, is running down. Longer term employees--and there are  many of them--have trouble accepting that fact.This is a defining moment for the United Way system and for the United Way of the Bay Area in particular. If rapid change and evolving ways of doing business make you nervous, this is not the place for you. If being a change agent is appealing, than look closely at this organization, because there is plenty of change being made.

pros: GREAT work/family balance, super flexible. Pay used to be terrible but with new CEO things got better, more fair. I love being able to flow between so many different constituents (non-profits, corporate, government, educational, etc.) - it is a very unique job and organization. I also love how it is our role to bring all of those entities together to work towards a common goal.
cons:
Waaaay too much turn over. Many non-profits experience this, but that doesn't make it less frustrating! When we had middle management there was an awful feeling of being their peons, they carried themselves so haughtily and were distant from staff. Once they left we all reported directly to the CEO, but now there's not enough accountability for staff that don't pull their weight.  

As an organization I think United Way's mission is noble, but personally I feel like they take on too much with not enough impact...they need to hone in on just a few key issues. They also need to not be so worried about politics...about what so-and-so will think if we do this, or how so-and-so will act if we do that. I understand we fundraise from influential people but that doesn't make them our lord and master.

review_title: It is not what it claims to be
pros: The pay,  benefits and lots of time off if you are regular employees
cons:
I used to work for for-profits and I found the work at united way is much simpler,  they raise fund,  make a cut,  and distribute the money the way they want it. They don't need to worry about taxation, product,  inventory and return/refund. What's complicated is the people - most of them,  especially the higher-ups,  don't care about the mission but the fundraising as it is linked to their performance bonus.  They will say and do whatever to make people donate to them.  Low admin cost is a joke,  they receive both public and government funding (for 211 and different grants). Just say they get $1m from each,  total fund raised $2m. Their admin & fundraising cost is $.4m.  They are deemed efficient at 20% cost, but it is indeed 40% if you don't count public funding,  which means,  $4 out of $10 you donate goes to fund UW,  then the remaining $6 get distributed to community partners who also have admin cost.  And let's not forget where the public funding comes from - tax payers money! It is not wrong,  but it can be done better. 

Working for United Way makes me realise that charity should be as small and focus as possible. Things get cloudy when a charity gets too big / high profile / with political agendas. Resources are limited and there's so much to do to make this world a better place.

review_title: Noble mission, good at partnerships, success highly dependent on immediate supervisor
pros: I have enjoyed working at my local United Way for the better part of 5 years. I have had the same supervisor the entire time who knows what they are doing and has solid management skills. Our United Way is great at connecting with the community, fostering productive partnerships, etc. The work environment is flexible. The vacation benefits are really good. Friendly people. Good opportunities for professional development.
cons: While the pay may be at the higher end of nonprofit salaries, after 4 years I should be making more than what I am now. At our small organization (under 40 employees), the highly corporate structure means little room for growth unless your immediate supervisor leaves and their position opens up. I have seen enormous turnover in some departments where the department head is a genuinely horrible person and the CEO refuses to terminate that person for the betterment of the company. One bad department head can mean a toxic work environment and constant walking on eggshells. That said, overall our leadership is good, if not a bit unconventional.

review_title: A great group, driven by a mission to do good for our community
pros:
A small yet mighty team (27 employees) with a lot of talented people.  Everyone who's here really wants to make a difference, each department pulling together.  Our yearly campaign regularly raises more money for the community than the year before...over $26 million in 2014.  Bigger cities are regularly put to shame by us and our community giving track record.

During the Fall campaign season, everyone is called upon to do whatever is necessary -- which is right.  We often have a little more flexibility in our schedules during other times of the year.
cons: We regularly are seen and heard by the top folks in the best companies all over town -- as such, we sometimes behave as if we're a much bigger outfit (and more corporate) than we really are.  Salaries are set and judged by our larger, corporate partners...yet we're regularly at the traditional "nonprofit" disadvantage.  No one else does what we does, as well as we do it.  And yet our salaries are a little low like all nonprofits.

pros: The organization is full of people who really care about helping others, including many people who have "been there" and really understand how hard it is to get by in our country. They are well funded and with a great reputation, which allows for a more relaxed work environment compared to a small non-profit and opportunity to experiment with new solutions for helping others.
cons: It is hard to get much done when fundraising seasons come around because upper management gets distracted and unavailable to direct projects. I would struggle with the decision if offered a management position because I'd need to spend less time on the real work and more time fundraising and doing PR.

review_title: Great nonprofit employer, but it is still nonprofit- Mile High United Way
pros:
Great team and talent. They really hire top-notch nonprofit people and they are very innovative within the nonprofit community. It is a great company for professional development and you will create a lot of good community contacts. 
Benefits are pretty good.
cons:
The mission is muddy. There are a lot of hands in a lot of pots and there is poor communication from the executive team in terms of where the organization is going. Expect to take a full year to actually understand what the organization does, and after that year they will throw in something random that really changes things up without much explanation. 
Advancement seems to be given to people based on popularity rather than specific work that individuals do. You may expand your department and grow and advance but if you don't have the right work style and personality you will be overlooked. 
While pay is better than most nonprofits, after a perfect review the most you can get for a raise is 3%.

pros: Helping others, agency support, disaster relief
cons: Culture, top management salaries and bonus for a nonprofit, not honoring contribution designations to specific purposes/agencies

pros: Truly loved working for a nonprofit and knowing what a positive impact United Way of Escambia County has on the community and the importance of the work it does.
cons: You are thrown into the job and are “trained” by your superior. Your superior has probably only been there a month and has no idea what he or she is doing.  No accountability for those in mid to upper management.  They are free to wander around the office and watch YouTube half of the day and take 2 hour lunches. Extreme regular tardiness (20-40 minutes or more) is commonplace for some employees and nothing is done about it.

pros: The many talented employees who are trying to make a difference.
cons:
This organization is one of the most unorganized and unprofessional places that I have ever experienced. There are no clear organizational goals and there are positions in all 3 departments haven't been filled in years. Also the turnover is outrageous with some people even leaving after 3 weeks.

They recently let go an entire department, and rehired their replacements, only to have more people quit shortly after that. The CEO turns employees against each other, and is solely responsible for creating friction between departments. Employees rarely receive acknowledgments or positive praises, let alone any bonuses or raises, yet she gave herself a 40K bonus last year. In addition to that, the COO was mysteriously let go under circumstances that was never explained to the staff. Lastly, outside consultants/board members with little experience are brought in to take over certain projects, instead of hiring a full time staff member. This happens because these "consultants" are friends with the CEO, and it has been made clear to staff that that is the reason.

This place feels more like a dictatorship than a company and it is really unfortunate because most people come here thinking that they will make a positive impact in the world - only to find out that they're making a positive impact in the CEO's pocket.

job_title: Account Executive in Oklahoma City, OK
pros: You get to make a difference in the community and can gain a tremendous amount of experience.
cons: You can make more at almost any other non-profit or even teaching job in the state. Lack of work-life-balance, high stress, lack of gratitude toward employees, you’ll have to do things over and over the same way, yet you’ll be expected to somehow get better results. Those who complain seem to get things a little easier, and if you don’t throw a fit, you’ll be running thinner than you could have ever dreamed about.

pros: The recognition and prestige of working for such a major organization in the Philanthropic arena including the broad exposure to dozens of client organizations across sectors and throughout the region. A good training program, front-line exposure and responsibility and a wide variety of opportunities to cultivate skills.
cons:
Temporary nature of position an the organization's approach to the position deminished the opportunity to gain traction, have a meaningful longer-term impact, fully develop much of what I started and made it difficult to quantify my direct personal impact in terms that translate easily for my personal advancement.
Tension between departments (Marketing, Development, Program) led to silos of thought and action which decreased effective collaboration.
The culture was not one of great mutual trust, respect amongst associates and so motivation suffered. There were several competitive/defensive forces at work that seemed to decrease team camaraderie, individual effectiveness and personal satisfaction. 
Poorly paid - no health benefits -- somewhat ironic considering the organization's mission is to create pathways out of poverty and yet it paid experienced professionals a wage on which it is difficult to live alone no less to provide for a family.

pros:
4 months’ internship experience in accounting and administrative field
• Thorough understanding of accounting principles including debits/credit, general ledger and subsystems
• Demonstrated knowledge of A/P, A/R, bank account reconciliations and cash disbursements/Receipts
• Adept at using MS Excel, Word and Quickbooks 
• Excellent data entry speed with accuracy
cons: In addition, I bring a wealth of other essential skills and qualities that I have developed through study and work experience: teamwork and communication, time management, attention to detail, presentation skills, customer service and the ability to meet deadlines. I believe that with my positive attitude and strong work ethic, I would be a great fit for the advertised position. I would apply myself with enthusiasm to all tasks, ensuring that I get the job done accurately an

review_title: Professional and Well Funded Non-Profit Environment
pros: Friendly but professional work environment.  A real career builder - highly respected in the community as a high performing organization and internally invests in personal career growth.  Excellent work/life balance, benefits and competitive salary.   Highly respected organization whose "product" contributes to the community.
cons: The non-profit culture isn't a fit for everyone.  Staff is driven to accomplish the mission but not driven to compete with each other.   Expect to be expected to be positive, solution focused and leave the office politics at the door.  The pressure to meaningfully contribute is constant, there is no room for coasting by or using office politics for job security.   Most United Ways are small organizations, UWW is just the branding provider, each UW has it's own board and own budget and runs completely independently.  This can mean limited opportunities for growth where staff size is under 100 or even under 50, simply because there are only so many positions opening up each year and only so much $$ in the salary budget.  Promotions and moving up the ladder can take 5-10 years for each step along.

review_title: United Way of Allegheny County is a great organization but lacks a cohesiveness
pros: Best reasons to work at the United Way is that you know you are helping someone in need.  Time off is fair and there is a belief hat family is first.  Health benefits are good but the retirement package is great!
cons: Pay is not on scale with other organizations unless you are at the top.  You can't work remotely and promotions are not from within the organization.  A lot of  contractors are hired to do work that the employees might enjoy but aren't privy to.   No incentive or real sense of  team exists.

review_title: Good benefits, but org structure outdated
pros:
- Good PTO (I think 5 weeks starting out, up to 7)
- All benefits fully paid (health, dental, vision), match up to 6% for 401k
- I don't know if they still do, but they offered a tuition program up to $5k if it was aligned with your responsibilities. One coworker was able to get toastmasters through it.
- Good people with good intentions, a lot of motivated professionals
cons:
- Overly concerned about attire (some guests/visitors shared that it felt like a fashion show)
- Feeling of inequity between departments (downstairs vs upstairs, development vs programs).
- Slow and unclear decision-making protocols; you may get approval for something from location/person a only to realize
- Pay was pretty low
- high employee turnover
- Regardless of workload, overtime wasn't allowed (even though many people did).

review_title: Great people but leadership is lacking - Salt Lake office
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: Some of the best people work at United Way which makes the job very enjoyable. A lot of hardworking individuals ready to make social change. They offer competitive benefits and have a great 401(k) match. Flexible schedules as well.
cons: In my years at the SLC United Way the leadership lacked the whole time. They do not want you to grow professionally. I've had former coworkers hired for one position, and years into that position express interest in moving up or changing positions only to be pushed out by management. The top protects the top, and only the top gets those big promotions. They aren't transparent with the work they are doing and how much money they are actually spending on 'big projects.' Sometimes they need to slow down and figure out how to fix a problem with the tools they have rather than jump into the next multi-million dollar project to fix another problem.

job_title: Community Collaborations Director in Salt Lake City, UT
pros: The team at UWSL is some of the best people I've had the pleasure to work with. While I was there under the previous CEO, there was a positive organizational culture and the work can be satisfying depending in which department you work. UWSL is not your typical non-profit as it feels very corporate in some ways. Really excellent benefits, particularly for a non-profit, flexible vacation and sick leave, and really great opportunities to network with high-level community leaders.
cons: Depending on the department you work in - you will experience different leadership styles. In the Collective Impact Department, titles, responsibilities, and focus is always changing. My title changed 4 times during the 2.5 years I was there and it made it very difficult to feel satisfied in the work when it was constantly in flux.  Also, the expectations are very high so it's difficult to have a good work/life balance.

review_title: Compensation can't trump a toxic culture
job_title: Capacity Building Manager in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Decent salary and benefits.  Nice office and location.
cons: Utterly depressing and unwelcoming place that reeks of distrust.  Leadership tries to micromanages and tightly control everything, to the extent that employees can't do their jobs.  You start to feel disaffected pretty fast.  There is no accountability; people who don't do their work or do it badly protect and enable one another.  Most senior employees have a petulant, antagonistic attitude towards United Way's community partners, which is shocking and offensive at first, but you get used to it because it is so commonplace.  The organizational culture is very white, elitist, and privileged, and yet leaders react reflexively or defensively if others address it (however tactfully).  If you luck out, you might get a decent manager, or you'll get someone incompetent, childish, and bizarre who probably should have been fired a long time ago.

review_title: Good benefits can’t override bad people.
job_title: Community Outreach Manager in Birmingham, AL
pros:
Salary is pretty reasonable. 
Benefits (PTO, insurance, and pension) are all great.
cons: They have people in positions of authority that create more problems than solutions due to their unethical behavior and maltreatment of staff. Unfortunately, senior leadership doesn’t seem ready and able to deal with those problematic individuals effectively so they are losing all of the good employees stuck under the bad management in the meantime. There is still a lot of potential for the agency to be resuscitated, but they need to be willing to deal with their issues first and they currently are not.

review_title: A fun, rewarding place to work
job_title: Campaign Manager in Baton Rouge, LA
pros: Laid back environment, familial relationships with co-workers, direct access to CEO, plenty of free food. The overall mission of the organization is great, it's deeply rooted in the community and there are no ulterior motives behind the work that they do.
cons: Typical office gossip can sometimes seem overwhelming in such a small environment, cliques are prone to develop, it's easy to become the odd man out if you're not careful.

review_title: Don't work here if you want to eventually make good money.
pros: Normal hours. Relaxed environment. Staff celebrations.
cons: The pay is terrible. The only way to ever make good money is to become a CEO of a local UW. Our CEO makes over $120,000, while some employees are barely at the poverty level. The VPs make pretty well, but there is still a very large gap. You MIGHT get a small pay increase each year, but it's never enough to make a difference. I have a college degree, but I was paid like I didn't have one. Employees at the bottom do all of the work. Employees are overworked, especially the fundraising department. All United Ways are different, but if you want to eventually make good money, this isn't the place to work. United Way does good work, but you can always volunteer. I need to pay my bills and I couldn't deal with it for very long.

pros: There are some great people here, and they're all really passionate about their work. The work-life balance is pretty good, with flexible schedules, WFH policy, and compressed work week options.  You get 2 hours of volunteer time per week, as well.  The office is right in old town Alexandria, by the water, which is pretty hard to beat.
cons: Everything moves very slowly here, as it's a big company that's been around for a long time. The benefits aren't great other than some of the work-life balance stuff, and the HR department leaves a lot to be desired. C-level execs seem out of touch with the needs of their employees as well as the needs of the field.  In fact, I saw the CEO for the first time after 6 months of working here, making an appearance at our internal fundraising campaign.  Your typical non-profit downside of lower salaries applies.  High turnover makes it tough to keep projects moving.

pros:
Of all the non-profits I've worked for this one has the most professional feel. It's an established non-profit and it shows. 

There is a great work-life balance (Flexible hours, some work from home).
Friendly atmosphere- not a lot of politics, bus driving,  and competition. People are generally friendly, and professional. 
Upper management is professional yet approachable.
Generous salary (for a non-profit)
cons:
Not a lot of cons, I really love working here. 

Maybe more work from home. So much of the office work from home on Fridays anyway, and there are so many commuters. It may make sense to just offer Work from home Friday to everyone who has been there for more than 3 months. Or everyone gets one work from home day a week. The office is like a ghost town on Fridays. It would save commuters time and money. It may even save the company on overhead costs (maybe).

review_title: Great Organization and staff but a few bad apples spoil the bunch...
job_title: Director of Business Development in Ocala, FL
pros: The opportunity to reach so many faucets for the community with the mindset to care for your fellow neighbors truly is inspiring. United Way as an organization is saving lives everyday as the backbone of their local communities. Its great that every United Way is autonomous allowing for local control (which could be good or bad).
cons: Point blank, I had to end my time because of my direct "boss". Poor leader, communicator, and DE-motivator. The two prior employees who worked under them also had the same issues. Micro managing, ego problems, insecurity, setting you up to fail. Just a office bully who high negative energy. The whole office (besides the CEO) feel the same so that is the most frustrating part to the organization. The community would benefit with a more positive work environment internally.

review_title: Disheartening, dysfunctional, unappreciative, top heavy, no vision or community outcomes
pros: Access to many nonprofits, but relationship building is not valued.
cons:
Relationship building is not valued.
No organizational vision.
No focus on making a difference in the community.
No value to outcomes.
Organization only values revenue and PR.
Not appreciative of hardworking, over qualified passionate staff.
Management hinders passion and innovative staff when trying to meet the needs of the community.
Senior management is not qualified.
Organization and senior management does not value its partners, they simply use them and never intend to give back (one sided relationships).
Salaries for lower level staff are disgraceful and Salaries for Senior staff are DISGUSTINGLY HIGH FOR A NONPROFIT (DONORS BEWARE).  Executive/senior staff turnout lends for a very unstable and unfocused environment.

review_title: Engaging and varied professional development opportunity.
pros: The ability to meet the higher-ups in a large variety of businesses and organizations is unparalleled, potentially leading to future career options, since the CE position is inherently temporary. The job also teaches a useful and flexible skill set, including public speaking and communication skills, relationship building and networking, data entry, and basic accounting. Little oversight means your manage your own workload. Pay can be negotiated and seems to vary by location, but is typically between $12 and $15. Overall a very positive and fun experience.
cons: Public speaking skills are a must; this position is not for the shy. Depending on your region, downtime may be common, even during the hectic campaign season (though this can sometimes be a plus).

job_title: Community Engagemnt Assistant in Windsor, ON
pros: It is truly an awesome place to work. You grow and learn and have fun while all the while you get to help others in a meaningful way to better their lives in any way you can. It is a truly rewarding experience and the management and everyone you work with are very helpful and everyone works together and there is no mistreatment or abuse of any kind. Everyone is respected and valued and the environment is really great to work in. Thank-you and  have a blessed day.
cons: The only thing that I can think about is it is hard to get in there on  permanent basis full time. Other than that, United Way is a wonderful place to work in and be at.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Free tea and coffee in the break room.
cons: I worked in marketing. Every few months, some marketing fad would be bruited about the office as the thing that was going to save United Way. Middle management would fly to DC for meetings with absurd names like "Tiger Team." We would have meetings and a half-assed implementation and then little would happen to change the sense of encroaching irrelevance, and then onward to the next big strategy. Someone was hired to fill the long-vacant position above me (he was a hilariously inept writer with very strange interpersonal skills) and when I asked for direction, because he was my supervisor, I was told "I'm not doing your job for you." I expressed my distress to someone a rung higher who eliminated my position as an end-run against our union defending me, then dumped my work on a colleague who already had her own responsibilities. It was, oh but truly, a shitshow.

review_title: Central County United Way Gives United Way a Bad Name
pros: Paid holidays during first year of work and paid vacation and sick time after one year of employment.  Beautiful office surroundings and some fun people to work with.
cons: Very low pay; one of the lowest in the area.  Very poor direction for the management and most of the time they never even come in to the office.  Very poor communication and lack of any formal training when I was there.  I was hired under false pretenses and never told the position was grant funded.  Also, I was hired to fix a mess from the prior employee and never given any direction from my manager on how to correct the situation.  Once I started looking for a new job, they tried to hire someone behind my back to replace me while I was still there!  Horrible for your carrer.  Don't bother working there.

review_title: Working at United Way provides rewards that exceed compensation.
job_title: Account Manager in San Jose, CA
pros: United Way provides a great work environment. The people are professional and engaged, and the benefits very good for a non-profit organization. The mission and goals, to make lasting change in the lives of people, provide a reward beyond the compensation.
cons: Past situations that have cast negative light on United Way, primarily due to actions of individuals, create an unfavorable perception by some members of the public with whom we are trying to work. Because this is a non-profit, and working to keep overhead costs at a minimum, most employees could likely earn more working in the corporate sector.

review_title: Excellent community work; terrible place to work
pros: United Way Ottawa really did do a lot of good for people in our community. Staff are given summer hours (every other Friday off) to compensate for all the mandatory overtime during the campaign year. The people working there were usually very friendly and wonderful colleagues.
cons: Management's treatment of staff was very poorly handled. Staff were paid badly, expected to work long hours and volunteer over and above regular hours. Education and experience were not matched with pay or responsibilities: many jobs that required highly skilled and educated people stated in their descriptions that they required only high school level education (and were paid accordingly). During changes in the workplace, all change was communicated terribly to staff, which resulted in a lot of anxiety and discontent among staff.

pros: You get the opportunity to work with several companies in a different capacity. This job develops the following skills: public speaking, account management, relationship building, database entry, sales, marketing, and event planning. This jobs allows you to get great exposure to the philanthropic community and gives you opportunities to network and build strong relationships.
cons: It can be difficult to manage a large amount of accounts, and that is why you will rely on your team heavily. You have to build relationships inside and outside of the organization in order to be successful. This is a temporary position so you need to know your next move, but still be dedicated and focused on the job.

review_title: Great place to begin your career
pros:
#1, the people you work with make this job the best. My team is extremely tight-knit and most of us are friends outside the office.
#2, if you perform well, there are significant opportunities for advancement. The leadership here really takes care of their best performing staff.
#3 The office is small enough that you will probably find yourself doing things that may not be typical of your "title." Some people may find this a disadvantage, but I love the huge variety of things that I get to do. It's an incredible resume builder. You have a lot of leeway to have a vision and make it reality.
#4 Salaries are competitive with other nonprofits, and their benefits (healthcare and retirement plans) are some of the best in the state.
cons: United Way employees a lot of students and recent graduates, so the turnover can be high, and responsibilities and structures can swiftly shift. This does keep things fresh and with new opportunities though.

review_title: Overall I am in the middle about UW. I learned a lot professionally but could not move laterally in 3 years.
pros:
There are many professional development opportunities. Classes, conferences, workshops etc. 
Also, the benefits are very good, especially for a non-profit.
cons: There is not much room for lateral growth. There is a very high turnover rate, especially in the fundraising department where I worked. Senior management seemed extremely incompetent and when a Senior Manager is hired who is competent, the board runs them away. The board can't seem to transition into the new era of philanthropy and workplace giving. Therefore, they tend to make decisions and often tie the hands of Senior management. It's frustrating to say the least but there are some really great people that work there.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: The kids are some of the best I've ever worked with. They are so excited to be there and are really appreciative and friendly. The staff is also a good mix of experience and new blood. Management is also pretty flexible.
cons: In a very non-profit fashion, your work follows you home. While on the clock, I generally ran errands for upper staff and helped to watch the kids. However, my actual job was much more than this and I often completed the rest of my work at home. If you want a job that doesn't bleed into your time off the clock at all or doesn't restrict your hours, this one may not be for you.

pros:
- Straightforward, simple work 
- A lot of holiday office parties, opportunities to volunteer
- Some colleagues are super supportive and friendly
cons:
- Low pay - IEUW  uses AmeriCorps funding to staff lower-level program coordinators. Pay comes out to about $7 an hour. Ironic that IEUW wants to help lower income kids from the Inland Empire go to college but then pays desperate college grads less than minimum wage.
- Other than 211 and some college-awareness work, the community programs are feel-good, very surface-level solutions to systemic problems in the Inland Empire. We give processed, salty food to under-resources kids but don't fund partner programs that teach healthy eating.

review_title: United Way HQ is big disaster
pros: Good mission and purpose. UWW provides lots of $ to local communities all around the world. Benefits are okay. Free parking. I was really excited when I got the job. if I was in graduate school, working at UWW would make for a great case study.
cons: CEO gets paid 750,000 a year. He says his job is to plan ahead five years. But, in the last five years, he has reorganized UWW 3 times. in the most recent re-org (11/2012) 60 people lost their jobs and none of those were executive management. Career paths don't exist in an organization that continually destroys itself. Morale, as you can imagine, is horrible. Directors treat staff terribly and VPs turn a blind eye to blatant mismanagement because they are afraid to lose their jobs. "Rules" are enforced erratically often due to favoritism and cliques. I wish I could say more.

review_title: Caution - No two United Ways are the same
pros: Many of the staff are hard-working, caring professionals
cons: United Way local branches operate like franchises and vary widely in their quality and management.  The branch that I worked for struggled intensely to fund raise as they continued to operate under an outdated model.  The lack of innovation was driving the organization deeper and deeper into a financial hole from which there is likely no return.  As a result, there was a pattern of layoffs and bully tactics to get staff to resign when financial outlooks for the year looked grim.  Overall organizational morale was low and leadership was more focused on self-preservation than in making strategic decisions that could have altered the future of the organization. Ultimately more dollars were going into sustaining organizational operations than were actually going to community goods and services.

review_title: Great organization to launch yourself from
pros: Nice people, great mission, VERY well respected organization in the community.  Good work atmosphere, fun employee activities.  For the most part people treat each other with respect, and there's very little workplace drama.
cons:
Tries to do too much, ends up not doing really anything extremely well.  Uses extremely outdated donor management software and stubbornly refuses to change even when it shows a detriment to the organization.  Considerable confusion about strategic direction of the organization.  

Very low salaries, little to no opportunity for advancement.  Most people work 2-3 years there to get it on their resume and then move on for higher pay.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Colorado Springs, CO
pros: Shorter waiting period for benefits to start than most places.
cons:
Lack of credibility in their message and what they practice.
Abuses the "and other assignments as needed" clause of the job description
Underpays and then continues to do so unless you are a VP of something in the org 
Currently, has a very toxic workplace environment

job_title: Visiting Executive, On Secondment in Ottawa, ON
pros: The United Way team staff, volunteers, students and interns work together in collaboration with a purpose and focus on making our communities and neighborhoods better and strong.  Lives impacted is our common mantra.  Making a measureable difference is our goal.  The generosity and fun that most bring to the community is also felt within the organization.  Happy t o be here :)
cons: As a not-for-profit in the national capital region, there is much talent and an assumption that the United Way is not competitive.  The work environment, learning opportunities, benefits, wages and performance pay program make for a very well balanced and comprehensive Total Compensation approach.

pros: Working at Heart of Florida United Way was a fulfill experience. As a contract worker at a local high school, my supervisor did everything in his power to ensure that my team and I were taken care of and that he was actively helping us in any way he could.
cons: Being a contracted worker, meant that I was not eligible for all of the benefits offered by Heart of Florida United Way. However, they did ensure that I was provided with medical and long-term term saving benefits. Likewise, as a contracted worker, there was little room for growth within the position, but that's more of a result of the type of work than any fault of Heart of Florida.

job_title: Program Director in Fort Walton Beach, FL
pros: This organization meant so much to me because of the agencies I had the privilege to serve. They worked tirelessly to make our 2 county area a better place. And we in turn worked tirelessly to help them raise funds for program expansion. Overall it was a casual environment with plenty of flexibility to learn and develop in multiple functions. You'll have the pleasure of working with passionate coworkers who care deeply about their community and are willing to sacrifice work/life balance to make a positive impact.
cons: There were several leadership shifts which led to a toxic environment and high turnover rates. You will struggle to find competitive rates here.

pros: United Way is the most business-like nonprofit and leads the sector thanks to an unparalleled local network. It's also a great place to work because you have family all around the world.
cons: It's a big organization with more than 2000 highly autonomous affiliates around the world.  Save for less than 1 cent on every dollar, all money is raised and spent locally.  That makes it difficult to standardize programs and services. Also neighboring organizations are notorious for fighting about who gets the money.

review_title: Great place to work, flexible hours, a lot of autonomy
job_title: Vice President, Development in Cleveland, TN
pros: What I appreciate about our affiliate is there is room to innovate and try new things, staff and volunteer leadership work hard to create a positive atmosphere, and the hours are flexible for those employees that are hitting benchmarks.
cons: Budget, budget, budget. We raise millions every year but our entire development and marketing budget is less than 5% of that. That makes it difficult to educate the community and increase our visibility. Additionally, the efforts of our fundraising team and program staff are not aligned fully. We also lack a system that adequately holds underperforming staff accountable.

pros: Great co workers, mission and commitment to programs and community,  It is great to work with so many people when you know that you share the common goal of working for good
cons: Low wages for employees, they want yo uto feel lucky that you get to be part of such a great org.  Which is a little hard to do sometimes when you are exisiting on left over break food, and ramen noodles.  At the same time, they want you to be financially commited to the mission.

pros: The corporate office culture is phenomenal with United Way. Everyone in our office is very collaborative and willing to help one another out. There is minimal drama between colleagues, which can be rare in a 100 person organization.
cons: There is a stigma associated with united way that makes it slightly more difficult to fundraise for the organization that you might imagine. Working to educate people on the work that UW does and attempting to change that negative perspective is part of the job that isn't in the description.

review_title: The summit of nonprofit careers in Utah
pros:
Work is efficient, actually achieves an impact
Best resourced nonprofit for the work it does
Well respected by all sides of the aisle, with wide and deep support
Salary and benefits is as competitive as it gets in the nonprofit world
Great place to position yourself to follow into a position in government or in the for-profit world.
cons:
At times, felt more like a Goldman's than a nonprofit.
In order to work with partners, there have been image standards that can be alienating to some.

pros:
It's inspiring to work for a great cause. The organization has a strong mission and the people are very dedicated. Compensation was pretty good for a nonprofit.

This is a good starting point for people interested in nonprofits, policy, or getting more experience in their field.
cons:
Different departments don't communicate with one another; hiring is slow and poor. There is a culture of working very long hours and making a lot of sacrifices for the job.

I would not recommend spending more than a few years here.

pros: Many colleagues were truly passionate about helping their communities, and were caring and devoted to their work. I met people I am proud to have as lifelong friends.
cons: I believe the experience comes down to the Senior Management of the local United Way where one is employed. The head of UW where I worked had no idea how to treat, motivate or respect employees. Also, new initiaitves were constantly being started with no regard as to the resources available to make those initiatives successful.

review_title: Does great community work, but needs to address employee difficulties.
pros:
-Great benefits
-Friendly work environment
-Fantastic work for the community
cons:
-Pulled a bait-and-switch on the job responsibilities after hiring.
-Some management is infamous for never listening to employee desires and complaints.  This creates a lot of tension, especially for lower-level employees.
-Perpetually understaffed
-Considerable turnover

review_title: Good place to start a career, not a good place for career advancement
job_title: Development Officer in San Francisco, CA
pros: Work/Life balance is a priority at United Way of the Bay Area. Comp time, plenty of PTO and other benefits are available to all employees. Employees in the Development Department are exposed to a wide variety of professionals and executives, making the position valuable for networking. Unionized work place provides job security as well as annual pay increases.
cons: Age and years of experience are valued far more than performance or productivity. Inconsistent HR policies (such as working-from-home privileges, performance reviews, etc) confuse employees and lend themselves to favoritism. Almost constant re-organization of company priorities mean that employees are constantly shifting projects, assignments and managers.

review_title: United Way Calgary leadership not the best
pros:
- Working alongside passionate individuals who are fighting to create a better city for everyone
- Work/life balance
cons: - The Calgary top leadership isn't great, their personal insecurities get in the way of the organization doing great things to move forward. There's a lack of trust and respect from the CEO to the rest of the employees, including the VPs. Employees are generally disheartened about the poor leadership and whether it can take the organization where it needs to go. Many people are leaving because of this.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Low expectations and lots of vacation time.
cons: Total lack of integrity on the part of leadership. Aging and ineffective board. Culture of routinely misleading donors as to where there donated dollars are going. Extremely top heavy, with six-figure salaries doled out to Vice Presidents running departments that have no apparent reason to exist. Total lack of concern over losing talent (and they are consistently incapable of retaining talent). Low morale. Senior staff get pay bumps every year (just look at the 990's) while general staff is almost never offered a raise. Further evidence of disfunction: a new CSO was hired with much fanfare - was given an entire team to work under him - and he quit just over a year later. I could go on and on. Sadly, clueless corporate employees continue to get duped into supporting the organization through workplace giving - mainly because they don't take the initiative to do their homework.

review_title: Great environment. Great Mission. Great team. Bad pay.
pros: UWCA is one of the nation's leading United Way affiliates, raising nearly $40M for approximately 90 of Birmingham, Alabama's best-regarded partner agencies. Professionalism, fundraising acuity, low overhead, and polished messaging make UWCA a great place to begin a career in fundraising.
cons: Pay is well below market value--at least that was the case when I was employed. I know people who persisted and now make more, but UWCA makes it difficult for a young person to stay on board, especially when those young people have direct access to agencies, donors, and corporate sponsors who are able to pay much more.

review_title: The org does good work, but the executive team makes working there intolerable.
pros:
UWSC has many policies that contribute to a good work/life balance.  Half-day Fridays, people can telecommute and a week off between Christmas and New Year's Eve.

Most everyone here is friendly and works well together.  People generally pitch in to help each other out.

Also, there are some excellent volunteers and great networking opportunities.
cons: There are a lot of rumors and low morale.  Promotions are not open to everyone and are not based on merit, they are only created for you if you are favored by the Executive Director.  It is very hierarchical and most staff feel like they have no voice.  They have a very "my way or the highway" mentality.

review_title: Great place to start a career
pros: As far as non-profits go, UWBA has the name recognition and more resources than most. You'll most likely have multiple roles and countless responsibilities, which guarantees you'll be learning and growing all the time.
cons: Turnover can be pretty high on the program side. And I worked there during a time of multiple layoffs, which meant you took on increasingly more work, without being compensated for it. Overall, it's pretty challenging living in the ultra-expensive Bay Area on the salary you'll receive, but it's still better than most non-profit salaries in the region. Out of necessity, UWBA leadership also seemed to change the organization's goals and strategy to  fit whatever funder at the moment could provide a large grant. That could be rather disheartening and exhausting.

pros: United Way offers you opportunities to wear many different hats, work out in the community and network. There were several employees who are no longer with the United Way that had great passion and had built strong relationships with other non-profits.
cons: This United Way had a very hierarchical working environment. Many of the employees had been there for a lengthy amount of time and were pretty rude and uninterested in collaborating and mentoring new employees.  The pay was under average as well.

pros: People are generally nice. Work is generally easy.
cons:
The mission makes sense but the goals are nonexistent which make it hard to sell to donors.

Departments typically work in silos with the hope that this may change but never does 

Finance is always looking for money which is nowhere to be found. Staffing here isn't the best but the org cant afford to hire competent finance people 

HR is nonexistent or might as well be. Theres no reason to have HR because an app can easily replace them. But why not waste money on non contributing staff

CI seems to think they are above everyone because they do the actual work or are grant funded but they dont bring any money in so unsure why they feel this way 

Leadership doesn't see what people on ground are doing but are getting paid the big bucks while people on the ground don't

review_title: Over 400,000 people in the 4-county greater Milwaukee area are being helped in their Education, Income, and Health.
pros:
- POSITIVE impact on people's lives! Numbers don't lie.
- Our daily work IS "making a difference", what most want in their present job - or seek in the next.
- Contrary to popular belief for nonprofits, pay is very market-competitive for like positions, and benefits are beyond.
cons:
- Positive community perception of 10% admin ratio impedes hiring of staff (translation: creates culture of "busyness" with little time for planning/reflection).
- Busyness drives some siloed behavior. Laser focus on own department due to only so many hours in a day.
- Intensity of work can easily cause some to loose sight of importance of interpersonal relationships at work.

pros:
This organization went through a massive transition, which is where most of these negative reviews came from. I am a fairly new staff member and it's very clear that some MAJOR changes were made with those critiques in mind. 

-Staff is really supportive
-Mistakes are viewed as learning opportunities 
-Shared goals, vision and mission
-Inspiring leadership team 
-Very competitive pay for the nonprofit sector
-Great location
-Measurable impact
-Great work life balance with tons of paid vacation days and the ability to work from home occasionally 
-Opportunities to volunteer throughout the year, which further connects you to the mission
-Supportive of staff applying to different positions in the company
cons:
-The physical space is a little bland
-Moving horizontally is much easier than vertically 
-Landscape for giving is slowly changing away from this model

review_title: Most disappointing job I ever had
pros: Good benefits.  Lots of talent in the organization.  Occasional pay bonuses. CEO often gives unexpected days off.
cons: The work culture is a culture of fear. Most people are afraid of management and with good reason.  People often get blackballed and  excommunicated from the  inner circle.  Eventually, they are fired or their positions mysteriously 'end'. There are unspoken expectations for your performance and then you're held responsible for the  results. People frequently assign blame and throw each other under the bus in meetings.  But worst of all, it seems like many people who work there don't care much about making lasting change in the community.  They just want to hang on to their stable jobs.

review_title: Great place to gain fundraising experience!
pros: They do not micromanage. Plenty of work/life balance. Strong brand recognition of United Way opens a lot of doors. We are able to work alongside and network with the leaders of the community from every sector.
cons: Can be a very heirarchal organization despite lots of claims that they are not. There can be a lot of internal politics. Gaining employee feedback can be useful but at times I think employees need to be simply held more accountable to fulfilling expected roles.

pros:
remarkable access to senior managerment. if you have a question, getting an answer is as simple as walking to the next door or cubicle and finding a solution

hard work is rewarded. whenever you or a colleague meets a goal or accomplishes something huge, there is a concerted effort to offer immediate recognition and praise company wide

satisfying experiences when working with clients/community members. because of the nature of the business, there is an opportunity to interact with various people/groups during your everyday course of work. no situation is unique and coming up with ways to better the lives of fellow philadelphia citizens is very very gratifying
cons: very heavy workload especially during peak season

review_title: Great place to be in the non-profit world
pros:
- Nice base salary in comparison to other organizations
- Great benefits 
- Flexible hours
- Friendly and welcoming staff
- Down to earth CEO and approachable leadership
- Advancement and personal development opportunities are supported by HR and upper leadership 
- Overall a super supportive staff that makes on boarding very smooth
cons: Some roles in organization are vague in job descriptions and can make on boarding a challenge when job duties are not clearly defined. If you're new to the non-profit world     be sure to ask lots of questions on the job and how that role helps the organization function as a whole during the interview process.

review_title: Do not go there, for your career sake
pros: reasonably flexible schedule; open, diverse culture
cons:
- lack credibility: empty promises.
- donor's money largely wasted on marketing events, videos and PSAs to promote internal executives themselves.
- senior leadership's non-profit, do good intentions are not real, not genuine.
- another senior management that just does not understand analytics, and confuses BI visualization with real data analytics and insights.
- very political environment.
- very unproductive.
- they'll make you donate > 1% of your salary if you work there. not voluntary donation, very surprised by this. they don't force you to donate, but pressure and atmosphere is that, if you don't donate, you know and you feel all around you, you won't be working there long.

review_title: be careful of not trapping into this organization
pros: people there are very friendly
cons: UWMC advertises hope, but people working there have no hope for any career advance. The whole management is extremely low efficient. And most of people working there don't even have a qualified degree! It is a really cheap organization. Don't get fooled by job title such as project manager, coordinator and etc. Even the entry level job will render you a manager title. If you are really serious about career future and you are capable,  don't waste your time there!!!

pros: United Way dwarfs it's closest human service competitors in terms of amount raised, the number of professional staff and volunteers, relationships with corporations, and geographic footprint.  As such, it has a lot influence over the sector at large.  Employees often find themselves elbow to elbow with the best and the brightest corporate leaders.
cons: Senior executives don't challenge the CEO and have a hard time sticking to a plan. Culture of consensus makes it slow/difficult  to advance ideas.

pros: Community Mission is admirable and the primary reason why most employees work there.  United Way has the distinct advantage of being a strategic organization that convenes community partners and approaches broad issues and to achieve measurable results.
cons: The organization is inherently chaotic and frantically trying to do a lot of things on a lot of different issues simultaneously all the time.  The inherent strength of convening a diverse spectrum of community partners also creates multitude of voices and divergent view points that must be heard and engaged to appease its immense body of stakeholders.

review_title: One of the best non-profits to work for!!!
pros: I love advocating for change and improving the community in which I live and work and raise my children.
cons: It is very hard to communicate what we do because it is so broad.  Because of this, United Ways across the world have seen a huge decline in their campaigns.  To make up for the losses, few United Ways are transitioning away from the "fundraising style" and moving toward a "community impact" style of operation which focuses more on the issues in the community, and losses are being made up with grants.

review_title: Use this as experience on your resume
pros: Great experience learning the business of fundraising.  If you are interested in learning the ins and outs of philanthropy and how to cultivate donors this is a great place to be.
cons: Lots of politics and racial undertones.  There are a lot of people that hire based on friendship and politics.  The climate can make you feel unappreciated and they are usually based on personal feelings.

review_title: Big hearts, good work and needs innovation
pros:
The people who work here are smart, friendly, warm and committed. We are doing really amazing work.  We are trying to break the cycle of poverty and I can't imagine something I would rather be working toward. 
Inspiring mission
cons: With a recent merger and other organizational changes in the last 18 months, we are in a time of transition.

review_title: I Really Enjoy My Job and Working Here
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: competitive salaries; fantastic benefits; open communications; constantly re-inventing itself to always be better and to offer better services; willing to make changes based on staff feedback when necessary; UWBA really cares about the community we serve.  I really enjoy the ability to work flexible hours.
cons: With the economy ever changing, the donorship tends to fluctuate so you can never count 100% on donations.

pros: There are some great people who work at UWTYR, altruistic, passionate about the cause.
cons: Lack of organization and direction, poor people management (in particular the department I worked in). Many 'lifers' who have been there for decades, resting on their laurels, lazy, always complaining, very gossipy (I guess that's what you get working with majority of women). Quite a toxic environment and even though it is a non-for-profit, it's very corporate and doesn't allow much for uniqueness or individuality. Conformity even at the expense of innovative ideas which they are in desperate need of.

job_title: Senior Director in San Francisco, CA
pros:
1.	UWBA - Excellent opportunities for professional development 
2.	Flexible working hours and other non-monetary benefits such as 401K matching.
3.	Superb opportunities to expand network by getting in touch with community leaders and influential executives who work on the boards and are sponsors.
4.	Great value of a work-life balance and people-oriented approach to personnel management. If you're a single parent juggling two kids' schedules as well as your own or pursuing personal goals like obtaining a Master degree, UWBA might approve scheduling changes or make other accommodations to help you succeed.
5.	Employees share a commitment to the same cause such as employments for youths and poverty reduction. Workers are compatible and have a sense of camaraderie.
cons: Slight improvement on the interdepartmental communication

pros: This is a great company in the sense that it's rewarding work and typically attracts great people. MHUW is friendly and gives employees the opportunity to be involved int heir work - volunteer and community work. People are willing to pitch-in and help each other on projects.
cons: High rate of turnover - management can be too focused on raising money and not recognize when employee satisfaction could improve. They could provide more real opportunities to work in other departments, rather than just talk about it.

pros: In a city that has personal and corporate philanthropy in its' DNA, the Tulsa Area United Way is the glue that holds it all together.  In addition to being one of the top 5 United Ways in per-capita fundraising, TAUW puts together collaborations and seeks to build the next generation of nonprofit leaders through our NeXTulsa program.
cons: Even though we have an outsized reach, we are still a nonprofit and our pay rates are conventional...benefits are good though.

review_title: TAMPA BAY LEADERSHIP NEEDS TO GET IT TOGETHER.
pros: In general, the work offers the community opportunities to "advance the common good."  Most of the relationships are positive within the organization.  Typically, most of the staff are competent and innovative.
cons: Lack of planning, poor internal communications, some executives are given privileges, overworked, under compensated, never say no to new work, little consideration of resources vs. new work.

review_title: Rewarding and enlightening making me want to do more to help seniors find employment.
pros:
Making a difference living united to help the 55+ market find employment.  We have 75 on my project's payroll and six others have found permanent jobs with benefits!  
Also, this job has enhanced my administrative skills including advanced excel and QuickBooks.
cons: The pay rate is so low, especially for my skill level and MBA in Accounting.  I am paid through a federal government grant and the position is limited to four years, and I cannot have wages from another job at the same time.

review_title: Not what I expected from a Non-profit
pros:
There is a sense that people really do want to "do good" for the community,  and some are there for that very reason. 

Excellent benefits with health and vacation time. They encourage you to volunteer and give you time to do so during the work day.
cons: There is no true direction. If you don't "play by the rules" you will not fit in. There are some very strong ego's and personalities that you have to work around. Pay is on the low side even for a nonprofit.

pros: The work environment is awesome as well as the people that work there. I enjoyed the worked I did for the community and would do it again in a heartbeat. The CEO is a wonderful person that is a pleasure to work with and really cares about the work that he does for San Bernardino County.
cons: As far as cons, I would have to say that they need to employ people that live in the community in which they serve to better understand what focus points should be addressed. Surveys should be implemented to better help the community to bring more opportunities and trainings to needy families.

review_title: Best Place to Work in RI
pros: There are many reasons United Way of Rhode Island is voted by employees as one of the best places to work in Rhode Island. The work is more important and relevant as ever. The people who work there are outstanding, especially the President and CEO Tony Maione. I loved my time there and really enjoyed working with a team of outstanding professionals.
cons: In a state with a struggling economy, raising money is a challenge. This puts pressure on the community investment budget. Also, as jobs decrease and the number of companies in the state cut back or leave, the pool of funders and donors shrinks.

pros:
I very much enjoyed working with our clients and doing my small part to help them. I also enjoyed working with my co-workers. The heartbreak many of the clients felt when they were dismissed was extremely upsetting. There were no valid reasons under the conditions of our grant to dismiss them.
The actual company name was "Central Texas Support Services of the United Way of the Greater Fort Hood Area."
cons: Management decided to eliminate 2/3's of our clients, creating problems for the company as we could no longer meet the requirements of our grant.

pros: Colleagues are nice, mean well and believe in the mission. Management is trying to improve employee satisfaction.
cons: Management is terrible. Local United Ways don't respect direction coming from UWW because everything is decentralized. Organization is trying to do too much at the same time, setting up unrealistic expectations and unclear deadlines. Not adapting quickly enough to changes. Mission statement is heartwarming and fuzzy but it's not how management treats its staff - this is a sentiment across many departments. Unless there's a change in senior management, the work culture will stay the same. Work-life balance is a sham. I would not have joined if I had known ahead of time.

pros:
I have worked for UW in Philly for about 6 years.  When I arrived, the organization was a well oiled machine. The CEO during the majority of my tenure, J.M., was one of the most energetic and gregarious CEOs I have ever met. Her energy was infectious -- I felt that we were truly a team that wanted to do great things for the community, so working at UW didnt feel like a typical job. It felt like we had a purpose.

I actually could feel and hear the impact (no pun intended) my work has done for others.

When I got to work every morning, I had zero desire to cause myself harm like I would at other corporate jobs. My fellow coworkers were pleasant, the atmosphere was relaxed. Days off were abundant. Business casual. Summer hours. Early dismissal fridays. Diverse. Salary was pretty good for the amount of work I was doing. I can honestly say that most of those positive attributes are still there.

The building's location is even awesome, right in the middle of the city. However...
cons:
J.M. was on the way out, and the temperament of everyone changed for the worst. We received a new CEO, one many felt did not mesh well with UW's vibe. It was all downhill from there. More meetings about trivial matters.  I also started noticing that gossip/backstabbing became more frequent, (especially in management) I had to stay at work longer and people were just randomly resigning/getting fired. 

I'm talking about people who were there for years, smiling to my face one day, shouting to the heavens about UW's message and strangely gone the next.  I'd log into my computer every morning and see " So and So is no longer working at UW." Jeez, we lost another one.

I figured that something was fishy.  It was then I had a feeling that one day, others would get that same email about me.  Turns out I was right, unfortunately.  I digress.  Cons --  For starters, I started losing my autonomy. The merger with other UWs brought in new overlords and more people to please. Cue the micromanagement. Cue the "we dont want to disappoint the new CEO" meetings. Cue the unnecessary changes to an already established system. 

Naturally, this caused the once oiled machine to explode into a million pieces. UW is not the utopia it once was. It's now another run of the mill corporate america environment. If you can stomach that, you'll be ok.

review_title: Great chance to make a difference
pros: The work is interesting, the people are on the most part engaged, and there is a feeling that it is impactful. The organization works hard to make sure that staff are connected to the work that they do, and see the benefit/buy in to the organization.
cons: For a charity, it is a big organization, and it can get bogged down in its size. Change can be difficult, and as a result can be felt by the whole organization.

job_title: Operations Specialist in San Diego, CA
pros: decent pay and benefits, good partnerships in meaningful areas
