cons: collective action requires more leadership. the ceo at the time was not a strong leader, and was routinely problematic. the staff demographics did NOT match the demographics of the communities they were serving, which would lead to tone-deafness at best and being very problematic at worst. it was discouraging to work as a person of color in the office (2017)

pros: All the employees truly cared about the programs and the people they were helping. This was extremely motivating and reassuring.
cons: As with many nonprofits, there was inefficiency in the process. Since there was so much work with the government, this created a lot of paperwork and slowed down so many projects that could have been completed quickly. That being said, I do not know how a nonprofit can improve too much on that.

review_title: A revolving door of temporary employees
pros: I felt good working for an organization that does such great work in the community. I enjoyed working with members of the community from diverse backgrounds.
cons: In my four month contract, I worked hard, enjoyed the work I did, and surpassed fund-raising goals. When my contract ended I was praised for my success and graciously thanked for my participation. However, opportunities for further employment with them were not offered, and my attempts to reach out to my former managers have been received unenthusiastically. Now I feel like I was just worked hard and ultimately discarded by a large bureaucratic organization.

review_title: Does not live up to their reputation of "Live United"
pros:
Largest privately held Non- Profit
Local United Ways help other non-profit agencies in their community with funding programs and link volunteer opportunities with corporate businesses.
cons: Company Culture is terrible.  Very little teamwork among departments.  No trust in upper management.  Very 9-1 top down culture.  Leadership mentality is "Do as I say, not as I do". Very old school and condescending environment.  Employee morale is low, lack of trust throughout organization.

review_title: A start-up feel with 90 years of history
pros:
1. Thriving culture
2. Work/Life balance is a priority
3. Great benefits with generous days off and personal days. 

The future of United Way is brighter than it has ever been – we have the resources, we have the fresh ideas and we have the passion to cut poverty in half by 2020.   I’m proud to be part of the UWBA family.
cons: Very fast paced...must be able to effectively meet the demands of proficient time management.

pros: The impact it has on the community. The core values are ones to incorporate into everyday life. The mission of the organization is one to be proud to be a part of. Great benefit packages, great work life balance, great work environment.
cons: Low wages, the work that is done doesn't equate to the pay. Sr. leadership makes substantial amount of money and receive bonuses but staff don't.  When campaign season brings in millions of dollars, but your told there isn't enough to provide a raise for staff or certain staff will receive merit increase, or a one time "bonus". It is slight discouraging.

review_title: A good organization, great varied experience, senior staff not great at communication
pros: Great staff. Fun people to work with throughout the organization.  A really good mission and a great organization overall. Org is supportive of ways in which employees would like to grow
cons: A bad economy means that everyone has to take on more, so a lot of people are overworked and stretched too thin.  It's good in that it's challenging, but does burn people out.

pros: Because of it's international reach and size, UW provides better than average resources than most nonprofits. It's a great way to connect with Fortune 500 companies if you're located in a big city, and allows you to see how to connect with corporate philanthropy.
cons: Definitely lots of hierarchy in the leadership structure because it functions very corporate-like. Lots of very structured process that is not always amenable to change. Sort of got a "do what's always been done" kind of philosophy.

review_title: Worked there part time...Good, not great
pros:
-The people are great, everyone is friendly and welcoming.  Even the executives take the time to reach out to the staff.  
-Great teamwork
-Organized
-Reasonable pay
cons:
-Not a ton of communication between departments
-Management changed frequently during my time there
- Not always a great connection between your job and United Way's primary goal, although as an employee you are able to seek this out.

review_title: I love the volunteer care clinic.
pros: The patients come from many backgrounds and countries and we see individuals of all ages with a variety of health issues. They are nearly all extremely grateful and happy to be receiving care--even though, in my case, being a phlebotomist, that care involves being poked with needles.  My co-workers are upbeat and anxious to learn and serve.
cons: The clinic only permits me to work one night a week because it is only open two night per week and many people want to volunteer.

pros:
-Organizational mission to solve complex social problems at scale.
-Company culture dedicated to celebrating successes, learning, and improvement.
-While it is a nonprofit, there is a for-profit feel/structure that is helpful for career development.
-Pay is above average in comparison to other nonprofits in Salt Lake.
-Skillset provided, there's opportunities to move within the organization.
cons:
-Limited upward mobility. It's a relatively small staff and the ability to grow and expand depends on fundraising.
- High pressure/changing workpace and environment. This can also be a positive because routine can be boring.

pros: Great benefits, little work. Front line work done by partner agencies. UW only works towards begging people for money.
cons: Asking others to donate yet internal staff are not generous on their own donations. Some people talk more than work. Others work from home or flexible hours only themselves and their supervisors know what they do. Many lifers there, turnover mainly due to jumping boat to government work with higher pay and pension, seldom jumps to private as work environment is too laid back and pay is relatively high for the work done.

pros: Employees contribute to making an impact in the community...decent racial diversity of staff...usually free food...salaries are decent for it being a NPO...most of the staff are democrats...
cons: Executive leadership all get paid six figures...lack of professional development for employees if they are not in the C-suite...every year, before the fiscal year ends, they will layoff employees to save money (and, they won't have to pay them raises - the review process is right after the start of the fiscal year, and that's how employees get raises, based on their prior-year performance)...executives often take credit for stuff they had no part in...TONS of drama and no one bothers to do anything about it...lack of transparency - lots of closed-door meetings that are related to personnel, not our impact work...located in boring office building with bad parking...the board of directors does not interact much with regular staff...execs often go to conferences where we use company $$$ to pay for their airfare and hotel stays, but reg staff don't get to go...lack of growth opportunities, does not promote from within, very siloed...most of the staff is female...the CEO moved from Maine and has found ways to bring in former staff to replace current staff - they all end up with great positions...horrible HR department for years...they bug you to take money out of your paycheck to give to united way, then spend the money recklessly, like bringing in a IT consultant, or paying moving expenses for new execs that can afford it anyways, or paying for execs to stay in five star hotels on their trips...they use volunteers for free labor quite often...the Sarasota office/staff is like a clique and doesn't like the Tampa office and vice versa...the office is a cube-farm; only execs get their office...always a lot of whispering and gossip...the marketing staff is the worst when it comes to drama, and they work whatever hours they feel like - the rest of us are expected to do the 8-5 thing...lots of unfairness...office is always freezing - or its brutally hot...office looks very boring, no decorations...execs play favorites a lot...an assistant opens all of the snail mail...lots of meetings that don't accomplish anything...events involve a lot of last minute planning...the fundraising team changes employees like people change their panties...we use this stupid computer program called andar...our bathrooms are always dirty...elevators frequently broken...etc.........

review_title: fun place to work, but pay was peanuts
pros: UW is a fun place to work. The people are wonderful for the most part and you learn much about the community you live in and the challenges of people that you might not interact with everyday. Gives one a sense of gratitude for what you do have in your life.
cons: Poor salaries for front line workers (admin, coordinators, assistants), yet these people do most of the work for the organisation. Working on weekends was sometimes part of the job. Executives showed little transparency in their decision. Culture of recognition was not evident.

job_title: Information and Referral Specialist in Cleveland, OH
pros: Rewarding work and friendly co-workers. The database is expansive and there is a lot of information available to you.
cons: Poor pay for the amount of work expected of you and the high stress nature of the work. Higher ups get paid a lot of money while the people doing the work on the front lines can barely survive. The benefits are terrible too, but it is a non profit agency so it's not really surprising.

pros:
United Way is a great institution that is going through a real growth period. Chapters in every region are learning to evolve by redefining philanthropy according to their community's needs.

United Way has deep roots and constantly pursues new public and private partnerships. I was proud to work for an organization that holds such a high standard for impact and progress!
cons: Workplace campaigns are evolving, which makes secure funding a little elusive. Keep reacting to the community and bringing smart people to the table, and the need for investment will be understood!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Organization has a worthwhile mission and is committed to fighting poverty though unique programs like SparkPoint. Staff across departments are motivated to make a difference and generally well-meaning. Excellent flexibility for employees and respect for work/life balance. Paid volunteer time for staff. Good location in SF, nice office environment.
cons: Poor internal communication and silos between teams, despite best intentions. Org structure doesn’t make sense – some departments are under-resourced, while others have dead weight, impeding progress. Significant disconnect between new, younger staff and long term employees who are “old school” and resistant to change. Very little accountability – if you have been there for a long time you can get away with being unproductive. Lack of clearly defined roles and processes creates lots of confusion and deeply inefficient work workplace. Although there is constant talk about innovation, very little actually changes and the organization continues to lag far behind when it comes to best practices in the nonprofit sector.

job_title: Call Center Representative in Columbia, SC
pros: Good money for being in a call center. Building was very clean and nice. Staff was okay most of the time.
cons: There is an "us vs. them" environment between admin and call center. Lots of favoritism going on in leadership. Loooooong hours, too long of a shift. Parking sucks. Can seem kind of childish co-worker behavior (gossiping, loud) - unprofessional at times. Slightly unorganized leadership. No room for promotion unless you are a friend and they create a position for you.

review_title: Good Pay, Good Experience, Not Progressive"
job_title: Senior Relationship Manager III in Charlotte, NC
pros: They paid very well for a non-profit organization. The local United Way agency here supports more than 80 member agencies. That can give an individual experience working with a variety of organizations and really getting a good understanding of the non-profit landscape in Charlotte.
cons: They were recently rocked by some scandal here in Charlotte. That led to reduced revenue and some layoffs. In general, the board is made up largely of corporate reps and the leadership in stable but not cutting edge or forward thinking.

pros: I loved the mission of the organization and I loved what I did, UWI is dedicated to their mission and sponsors a wonderful literacy program.
cons: There was one individual in the office with a particularly nasty attitude and the head of the organization overlooked, I would even say enabled it. This person's presence changed the atmosphere from fun to dreadful, you never knew what she was going to say or do next. Many outbursts. Hard to be productive.

pros: For the past century, United Way has sought to serve the needs of metro Detroit's human service agencies and the increasingly needy populations they serve. The people who work for UWSEM tend to be highly motivated to serve others, willing to put in long hours and do whatever it takes to get the job done. Whether working to support the logistics of the annual fundraising campaign, or to help maximize the value of dollars raised for the agencies supported by United Way, the people who work in United Way are the best of colleagues.
cons: There seems to be a sizable gap between the management's ability to talk a good game and actually deliver results. Judging from his demeanor at all-staff meetings, the CEO is a personable guy with an attractive self-deprecatory manner. Unfortunately this impression does not stand up to close scrutiny, especially over the long term. The term "management by walking around" seems to have escaped him. He prefers to engage with problems in theoretical fashion, rather than by realistically assessing the human (and other) resources available to him and going from there. As a result, staff are asked to get behind one grandiose plan after another - but none of them ever quite work out because the guy loses interest and moves on to something new.  A further symptom of this malaise is the management structure, which is byzantine in its complexity: new titles for departments (and department heads), juggling of staff from one management silo to another, failure to define people's responsibilities (or even the jargon used in job descriptions) - no wonder people outside the organization tend to say "chaos" when asked their opinion of the organization.  Finally, there is the sense that UWSEM (like many other United Ways across the country) has outlived its usefulness in some ways. The days when corporations saw an advantage in working with United Way on a corporate in-house campaign are, if not over, surely numbered. The organization needs to redefine itself in some way that makes its survival essential to the well-being of the non-profit sector in metro Detroit. Although efforts continue to be made in this direction, the "essential" element is still missing.

review_title: In the beginning, it was promising then towards the end of the first month, senior management was uncooperative.
pros: It is rewarding because you are personally involved in helping to change an individual's life. It is also a pleasure to witness the end result(s) of all your hard work.
cons: The senior management team are a corrupt group. If you're not well-liked, they will make your job very difficult by sabotaging assignments, deleting emails, and making themselves unavailable when you need their cooperation or signature on projects. It was hell.

review_title: United Way of Greater Philadelphia and Southern New Jersey
pros: The staff really care about what they do and help make the working environment great.
cons: The organization changes their vision so often and does so without a plan making it difficult for staff to do their job. They have struggled in recent years based on antiquated model and technology. Organization is slow to change, lacks strategy and is overwrought with bureaucracy.

job_title: Development Associate in San Francisco, CA
pros: Social mission, feel good to help others, generally nice people work here.
cons:
No pay, minimal benefits, no growth opportunity, deadend job. Managers have no skills in managing, consistent throughout organization.  
Good place to volunteer or come if you not looking for pay, recognition, or growth and have other means to fulfill those needs.
Does not promote from within!!!!

review_title: The UW agencies with positive reviews are with trained and experienced leadership and a solid, believing, active Board.
pros: The UW still has a fairly resonable reputation, however they need to find better ways to include and moniter new agencies, and while some staff have a excellent ear and insight to feasability of local agency leadership and could be supportive of building agency competency along the way, the opportunities just do not seem to be there.
cons: Very little, if any, national or regional support for small local programs, nor did it seem that the support was apparent over the previous ten years.

review_title: Love the work we do but negative working environment
pros: You get to make a tangible difference in the community and hear some incredible stories from people in the community. The volunteers who help with campaigns are also great.
cons: Our office in particular is always so dramatic with very little collaboration between departments. It is hard to be innovative and the on-boarding process for new employees needs a lot of work.

review_title: Give. Advocate. Vounteer.  Be United in your community through United Way.
pros: Community involvement and leadership.  Working for United Way is a very visual position - everyone knows who you are.  Which of course can be good (networking and career advancement) and bad (you can't run to the grocery store in your sweat pants at 11:00 at night).  As long as you maintain a high quality work product you are in good shape.  Unfortunately past impressions of a weak board and weak leadership has caused some individuals in the community to withdraw their financial support, so a lot of what I am doing is re-relationship building, which fortunately is something at which I am accomplished.
cons:
No health insurance, no 401K.  It really stinks that an organization that prides itself on "providing for those in need" doesn't provide for its own employees.  In my organization's defense - we are very small.  There has been some rumor of consolidation and regionalizing over the next 10 years.  If that does happen, then the number of paid employees will increase and the organization might then be able to offer a benefits package.  
Another downside, and this may have been because of poor previous management, is the lack of resources and lack of vision.  When I got here the newest computer in the office was 10 years old. 10!!!!!!  And no technology budget in sight.

review_title: Rigid Hierarchy that doesn't value most employees or utilize them well
pros: Many of my colleague are very talented and hard working (especially at mid and low levels).  Working remotely is normal and the office space is nice.  Some of the work UWSEM is doing in communities is incredible.
cons: Although we are a relatively small organization, many people don't know each other who should and others have never met our leadership at all.  There is no sense of team, no on-boarding for employees, and much time is wasted because of this.  Some teams in UWSEM are more organized than others and some teams don't even have regular meetings at all so the work can feel very isolating.  Many projects are not staffed at appropriate levels and many promises are made that more staff are being hired, but that rarely happens so burnout is very high.  Leadership doesn't usually give time to listen, they just talk at us.  We work remotely, but our servers and remote access is often not working which is very frustrating and never seems to get better.  StrengthsFinder is highly valued by the organization, but it is often used incorrectly against staff to focus on their weaknesses.  I often see that making something "look good" is more highly valued by leadership than making something that has the most positive impact on community. The "leadership" team makes promises to donors and funders without knowing what is possible on the ground and it gets us into some very tough situations.  Evaluation is talked about a lot, but an afterthought.

review_title: Excellent, would have worked there forever
pros: Great place to work. Great work life balance. They really care about family. And they are a "work family" such a great environment to be in every day. Very flexible!
cons: Working at United Way you have to care about the job! NOT the money. Obviously it's non profit so you can't expect a amazing salary. But they are fair.

pros: As a site manager, there is never a dull moment. Each day is completely different and will bring a brand new problem, so thinking on your feet is very important. You learn a great deal about the community, and I felt very connected to the mission.
cons: Working at a tax site can be quite stressful and it is easy to feel disconnected from the main office, as they have specific goals for your site than can be unclear.

review_title: High turnover for a good reason
job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: A number of my coworkers were excellent people but they generally fled the organization within a year for obvious reasons.
cons:
A useless bureaucracy managed with maximum dishonesty. Nobody was ever able to say quite what we did other than raise money. There was vague talk of our advisorial or administrative role in programs, but mostly just a lot of empty business lingo, meetings about other meetings, and desperate attempts to appear relevant so people would continue to donate. 

I was there under a year and more than a dozen people in substantial positions jumped ship.

review_title: Doing More of a Disservice to Employees
pros:
Those doing the work at the entry and mid-management level have a heart for service and strong intellect.  You will learn a lot from these individuals.

As this organization is very well-connected within the Orange County community, you will have a lot of opportunity to network with high-powered individuals within successful public and private organizations.

Additionally, because of the high turnover rate, there is a lot of opportunity to potentially advance.
cons:
If you are looking for a leader willing to listen to the data and the field-level team actually implementing the work, OCUW is not the organization for you.  C-level leadership often acts on beliefs and whimsical ideas instead of leaning on best practices or proven statistics.  Moreover, income goals that are expressed to the public are based on pledges that often do not come to fruition.

There is no opportunity to express concerns without being met with defensive responses or complete ignoring of the proposed problem discussed.  Without accountability applied equally across the portfolio of employees, those without the skills, proven track record or knowledge of the position are promoted prematurely or simply because of who they know.  There have been several instances where complaints about the professionalism and work of an employee have simply led to that individual being moved around - at the same pay rate and title.   In those same instances, C-level leadership have openly discussed in front of subordinates the negative feelings and distrust they had of those employees -  thus leading to an environment of inappropriate conduct and tension.

There is a strong reliance on third-party contractors, who charge exorbitant fees, that is a poor use of donor funds.  Moreover, there are great conflicts of interests as a handful of OCUW employees have used their current positions as platforms for political gain and past Board members who have used their former status to gain a leadership role at OCUW.

review_title: Excellent 2 week training to prepare to coordinate workplace giving campaigns
pros:
Raises over $20 million locally to distribute to community non-profits.
Mostly dedicated employees.
cons:
Emphasis on employee diversity over employee competence.
They ask for feedback but then don't keep on people who speak up or think outside the box.
Way too laid back culture; incredible waste of work day time.
Top CEO and VP/Directors are very highly paid. The rest of employees are paid at local non-profit levels, which are not a living wage.

pros: I only did it for credits but it's a great way to be a tax expert by talking to people and prepare their return. Those site coordinators were really helpful.
cons: I feel their resources did not evenly spread out, because some of sites, like my place, had to take at least twenty taxpayers in the morning, and things got more crazy on April 15th.

pros:
Some of the brightest and most talented individuals who are mission driven to better the Denver community work at Mile High United Way. 
Employees are very friendly and work in a collaborative way to get things done. 
The organization has a solid brand name in the community and is effective at working across sectors for the community.Really incredible benefits.
cons:
Lack of autonomy at almost all levels of the organization.
It's all about who you know- to get hired and to get heard
Not very good pay
Lack of transparency

review_title: A great organization for agencies who need funding- but a bit more challenged in the employer area.
pros: really works for working moms. Fairly flexible with the work from home policy.  Understanding overall of life situations. Some really intelligent and well connected employees.
cons: In a constant state of change. Seems to operate like a start up. Not very transparent about the few growth opportunities that are available. The work load nowhere near matches the salaries.

review_title: Passionate Colleagues, Working for the Common Good
pros: Some of the brightest people work there and higher education and intelligence is valued.  Creative and motivated team members who consistently go above and beyond to meet management expectations.
cons: Management expectations.  The nonprofit world is changing and UWS has tried to keep ahead of the curve with innovative programs and partnerships.  Management  seems too far removed from the work though, especially as the organization has continued to merge with other UWs and expand.

review_title: Competitive pay, changing organizational strategy, mixed bag of leaders
pros: Pay and benefits are competitive with other nonprofit organizations in the Twin Cities. Most managers are wonderful, and there is a mutually supportive atmosphere.
cons: Tense time right now (2019) with new LRP strategy causing organizational changes. Some executives and managers are not so great due to a disconnect with employees or poor management skills.

pros: Good work environment, corporate feel, great connections. Overall a great workplace for those in non-profit, especially if you can find yourself the right spot.  Affordable benefits package.
cons: As all non-profits, compensation is on the low end.  Would like to see greater HR involvement in staff development. May be a little too political at times.

review_title: A great organization to work for with like-minded people working for an important cause.
pros: The people, a great mix of young and old and from all over the place. You feel good about the work you do. People are flexible and understand the importance of having life-work balance. Started as a temporary employee without benefits and PTO, but after 6 months received them.
cons: Most people tend to be over-worked and under-paid, as with many non-profits. Not tons of opportunities to move up.

review_title: Great company, and little slow moving
pros: I loved the culture and people working at United Way. They are a fun organization to be at, and folks genuinely care about making a difference.
cons: Because of the pay, many folks can be a little inexperienced and often use the organization as a way to head start their career. So on the downside, a little more turnover and a little less experience than I would have liked.

review_title: Great brand - not so great environment
pros:
Great brand, good reputation
Good for experience
Professional 
Good for the community
Most people want to help others
Can make good contacts
cons:
They "package" everything rather than truly trying to make a difference.
Management does not trust employees.  Favoritism too - if you're favored, there is no accountability even if you're in management.

review_title: The best Place to work if you enjoy helping people and enjoy what you do this is a place for you.
pros: the good thing about united way is there is a verity of things you can do here and those range from HR to IT even Community impact you will enjoy perks of working here like going to other company HQ for tour and more.
cons: There are no cons the leadership is great you just have to be energetic because that's the atmosphere we work everyone is fired up.

pros: This work allows for you to engage in community work and meet people on their level. You learn a lot about managing and reviewing grants, along with understanding the need of community organizations.
cons: It's a struggling non-profit and will go as far as leadership within the community supports it. Its been some leadership change within the organization, but now it's stable and should grow.  Small office, not much growth.

pros: Sadly, there are no pros to working at UW. The agencies that partner with UW are amazing in their work. UW loves to glorify their work as if it is their own, but that is not the case.
cons:
- The CEO / VP lead in as though the company is an authoritarian dictatorship. They do not care for the well being of their staff and are not flexible. 
- Favoritism is played to certain employees (mostly directors) and staff are micromanaged.
- No opportunities for growth or PD. 
- High turnover. CEO will tell the Board it is because of better opportunities with higher pay but that is not the case. 
- Directors will have closed door meetings and gossip about other employees.

review_title: Challenging, rewarding and room to grow.
pros: You get to work with some of the greatest people you'll ever meet. We're incredibly diverse and inclusive. Staff range in age, geography, race, etc. It's really easy to make friends and even the folks you don't go to hang out with on weekends are still really great at happy hours.
cons: We're tackling a big agenda, often on less than adequate budgets. Compensation isn't great, but probably competitive for the sector when you factor in benefits. Work-life balance can be difficult to maintain.

pros: Great entry level position. I learned a lot of program and project management, conducting community needs assessments and evaluations, how to use SPSS software, and how to coordinate and liaise with stakeholders and partners. I also had an opportunity to present final reports and give presentations in front of the Board of Directors.
cons: Little opportunity for growth and very low salary for entry and mid-level positions.

review_title: Easy, fun work environment but lacks structure
pros: Very laid-back environment. Departments have easy communication and everyone jokes with their teams. Connected to almost every agency in the area and a lot of funding sources.
cons: Communication between departments is almost nonexistent. No one knows what people outside of their department do and often are wasting time doing the same work that could just be collaboration. Things move slowly and you often execute an initiative before you actually develop a program guide and evaluation measures.

review_title: Great stepping stone in career path (CA area)
pros:
Dynamic and meaningful work
Coworkers who care about each other and community
Opportunity for personal development
cons:
Uneven quality to staff in terms of competence
Management on conservative, risk adverse side
Not enough diversity in staff

pros:
mission- focussed mission benefitting nonprofit local organizations that are vetted and then supported over a long period of time.
professional - strong teams with industry and nonprofit backgrounds
cons: Management turnover of office leadership slows down progress of employee's development.  Some offices have entrenched workers that can be slow to adapt to technology for example. Individual volunteers less likely to be supported thus alientating future potential donors.

review_title: Heart of West Michigan United Way
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Wonderful employees (for the most part).
cons: Very high turnover. Elitist, out-of-touch Board of Trustees.  Poor management and a hapless CEO who is leaving after inflicting deep organizational damage. Heart of West Michigan United Way's reputation in the community has suffered and the office culture is awful. The turnover rate is very high. Talented people don't stay here.

pros: Positive, supportive team who are passionate about the work they are doing for the community. An excellent training program within the first week. Autonomy. Many opportunities to practice presenting to groups of 2-100 people.
cons: Some early mornings or late afternoons / evenings, as campaign events may start earlier or later in the day depending on the workplace.

pros: The organization encourages growth and development and the job itself is very rewarding. I learned a wealth of information and skills and very much enjoyed each of my colleagues.
cons: For a non-profit, the salary was generous, however, it is still relatively low compared to that of a small business or corporation in the area. I wouldn't consider this a con since this is the nature of working for a non-profit and to be expected.

pros: Everyone works very hard to help communities in need. The people that work there are very passionate about the work.
cons: I'd like top see all of Southeastern Michigan benefit from their work. Not big enough to grow within the company. Compensation is higher for those that came with new management. All others are left behind. Truly disappointing.

pros: The United Way is great at staying focused on their work for the community and raising money.  They are conveners who bring the community together.  One gets great satisfaction working here, because you feel you are making a difference in people's lives.
cons: Leadership is so focused on their work of the community, they forget about their own employees...one had better be a self-starter and work independently, don't count on being mentored, or having help.

pros: There are brilliant, well-meaning professionals that are dedicated to their communities that work here. Great work-life balance. Tons of professional connection opportunities. Great learning and development opportunities.
cons: Huge disconnect between United Way World Wide values and local United Ways. Organization is white-washed and classist, (oddly enough). Complete disconnect between employees and communities served.

pros: Co-workers were nice and always did great team building exercises. Good benefits
cons: Management was terrible. They did whatever it took to have the type of reputation that was expected. I thought it would be a great place to be apart of and the more I learned about it, the less I wanted to be apart of it. They make the appearance in the community, but after taking a look at the overhead and the big wigs salaries, it was sad. Not the 501-3C I expected to work for.

pros: The president of the organization is a fantastic leader. He works hard alongside his employees and never asks them to do something he isn't willing to do.  The Board of Directors are phenomenal and are very supportive of the organizations mission, as well as its employees.  The internal culture is great- with employee events, incentives, and team building happening annually. Really a great place to work and serve the community.
cons: With limited staff, the work is hard- and it is nonprofit salary.

review_title: A fantastic organization of committed individuals doing important work.
job_title: Director Business Development in Austin, TX
pros: A relaxed but professional environment, surrounded by passionate individuals who are collectively working hard to make a significant difference to the community they live in.
cons: United Way could benefit from an increase in cross departmental collaboration. Often times the individual departments have limited interaction/contact with each other and this leads to a lack of understanding/mistrust of the important roles played by each department.

review_title: Love to work for this company.  While the work is challenging, the work is rewarding.
pros: Excellent mission driven organization.  Top management is competent, compassionate, and determined to perform well.  Company has a solid reputation in the community.  Management and many employees have a long history of working for this company.
cons: Being a smaller company, room for career ladder growth is limited.  Every organization has some drawbacks, but I really can't think of any that would lead me not to recommend this company.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Very open to new ideas and new ways of thinking as they explore how to make the greatest impact they can in the communities they serve. Very inspiring place to work, and I get to be creative. Every voice that speaks up is heard.
cons: There are so many opportunities to do new and better things that it's sometimes difficult to prioritize those opportunities. The pace can be fast, too, which sometimes leads to a breakdown in communication but that seems to be improving.

pros: Pay, benefits, generous paid time off, laid back atmosphere, some nice people work there
cons: To be honest, it's a scam. It lures donors to donate for causes that are not measurable. Lots of sobbing stories of how UW changes people's lives but I always wonder how true that is, stories are way too positive and exaggerated. Performance metrics are jokes. Many lifers at management getting fat pay cheques enjoying perks and benefits. Heavy workload for bottom staff who are underpaid. ET team treats the organization as ATM. board members are from same golf or yacht clubs.

review_title: Good people, decent benefits and pension, a lot of work
pros: Best thing about this organization is the people. There were lots of good people within the organization and it overall has a nice caring culture.
cons: Work life balance can be an issue. Management tells you WLB is important but there's just too much work to get done without doing overtime on a regular basis. Like many other workplaces I'm sure, this organization is also not fair across the board. I have seen unfair treatment, favourtism coming from the top.

pros: Family atmosphere, great space to work, collaborative environment, complex social issues
cons: lack of employee development opportunities, lack of feedback on job performance, too little day-to-day leadership, decisions made with hardly any data to back them up, willy nilly spending of money, high focus on fund raising with seemingly no clue of how to use the money once it's raised.

pros: Good benefits although they are becoming less and less available,
cons: The administration befriends who they would like and that is the only way to move up within the company. When you first begin working they advertise the possibility of moving up or changing positions but that rarely becomes available and if it does they already have chosen a friend to take on the new duties. company doesn't seem to care about the well being of certain departments and the company is very segregated.

job_title: Lead Preschool Teacher in Miami, FL
pros: Great benefits, very competitive salary, lots of opportunities for professsional growth and learning.
cons: Tons of paperwork, lot of pression to be perfect in everything, administration lack of fair management in terms of treat all  staff equally, it is not an average 8 hours job.

pros: Fair compensation that is reviewed regularly to stay competitive with market rates, passionate and committed co-workers that care about each other, opportunities to lead a variety of projects, access to leadership
cons: few opportunities for career advancement, may have to leave and come back

pros: This place fosters impact, leadership, initiative, and grit.  Not for the weak, as the work is fast paced and tough.  Everyone has best intentions and all work hard.
cons: We are in the middle of leadership change, which is good, but you have to have an appetite for the complexities that comes along with it.

job_title: Campaign Account Manager in Tulsa, OK
pros: The Tulsa Area United Way is the premier non-profit organization in the Tulsa-Metro area.  Their annual fundraising campaign supports 60 area non-profit organizations, multiple community collaborative initiatives, and funds innovative projects throughout the area.
cons: Because their 3 areas of focus are Education, Health & Safety, and Financial Stability, they are limited in the organizations they can provide funding to.

job_title: Development Executive in San Diego, CA
pros: Very connected to the community, innovative and collaborative work, access to top companies and leaders, flexible work schedule, great team environment
cons: As with all nonprofits, salary and benefits are not as high as they would be in the private sector.  Smaller staff size leads to heavy work loads which is standard with any non profit

pros: It is nice to know that the money raised goes to community programs. Also, you get to learn about different agencies every day.
cons: It's a bit disorganized/dysfunctional and the leadership often lacks focus. Very nice people but they change their minds on what they want to do A LOT; leaving employees confused or hesitant on how to move forward.

review_title: TAMPA BAY UNITED WAY NEEDS IMPROVEMENT
pros: An effort to improve the quality of life for people with special needs.
cons: Poor senior leadership, easily diverted from primary goals.  The organization spends too much time with internal projects and not enough time getting out and doing things in the community.

pros: if you can act just like directors, you are good to be there, otherwise run away.
cons:
worst culture ever. Favoritism to the most level. 
it is all about the directors and tricking people to get money out of their pocket in the name of kids, service, and education.

pros: Responsible for a variety of work, research and social media management. Flexible work environment with very friendly and encouraging staff members. Independence in work and team-work opportunities.
cons: The summer is a less active time at the United Way and therefore I was unable to see the inner workings of fundraising throughout the year.

pros: The organization has potential and there are definitely some very talented people working there. It is a great place to network and meet other leaders in the community.
cons: No vision. The organization is constantly chasing new program opportunities and lacks the focus or the courage to do what is necessary. Lots of turnover mainly do to very little upward mobility.

review_title: Steeped in tradition, unprofessional and not collaborative
pros: Good work life balance that offers a flexible schedule
cons:
Organization is not structured to support collaboration; Almost seems to discourage it
Many people have been there or in non-profit a long time, sometimes making them seem complacent or even lazy
Some of the senior leadership are often closed-minded to new ways of doing things

pros: The mission of the organization is clearly the reason to work there - making a positive impact in the community is almost worth what they put you through as an employee.
cons: Decision making process changes continuously.  there is high turnover among senior leadership which causes instability.  The biggest problem is that the executives say the right things but then do whatever is convenient at the moment.  They talk the talk but they don't walk the walk.

pros: Community action, genuine desire to serve local community, stays consistent with mission and vision, transparent financials. Fiscally conservative and good local resource.
cons: Very high turn-over. Poor employee engagement. Lack of trust within the organization, especially between employees and upper management. Poor job/career role expectations - almost deceptive, very unclear as to what you should be doing or what you were hired for or when/how role may/may not have changed with very little useful feedback or communication. Poorly run.

pros: Get to feel like you are helping someone everyday. Strong benefits, nice co-workers, excellent flexibility to work from home when needed.
cons: Poor leadership from the top. Senior leadership is out of touch with front line staff and communication is poor. Mid-Senior level managers are inexperienced and ineffectual.

pros: Many connections, working towards a common goal, positive environment, public speaking training, flexible schedule due to hourly pay, great people
cons: A lot of cubicle desk work, can get very hectic during the end of the campaign, only a temporary job, no room to move up, having to ask people for money can be hard

review_title: people are committed to making a difference and like each other; friendly
pros: great benefits, friendly people, challenging work, public exposure, committed to training and development, paid time off generous, family friendly, exciting work
cons: fundraising is challenging in economic environment, must be creative in setting priorities and using limited resources, must be willing to be a generalist

pros: Part of an exciting global movement to transform communities in the areas of Education, Income and Health.  Great professional nonprofit with innovation and change at the heart of the culture and mission.
cons: Long hours and true commitment needed.  Great career for the right individuals that thrive on change and leading complex community work.

pros: Some great colleagues and new office space. Long-running brand.
cons: More than a year's worth of reorganizations and staff turnover have left UWGT with nearly non-existent institutional knowledge and few robust systems to support strategic impact in the greater Triangle community. The new CEO is ill-reputed by many in the community that have worked with him, ill-prepared to lead this complex organization, and ill-tempered when encouraged to consider facts contrary to his opinions or decisions.  Board leadership is disengaged. Strong vision for the community simply isn't there and, were it there, organizational capacity to execute on the vision and facilitate sophisticated solutions to nuanced community issues is limited.

pros: Caring, smart people. Competitive salaries for nonprofit sector. Chapter-based structure - no single United Way is the same. Opportunity for front line management training, opportunity to impact changing business model.
cons: Again, chapter based structure - no single United Way is the same. 100-year old fundraising model is in flux, with chapters needing to quickly figure out how to adapt.

pros: Good for experience if straight out of college or for learning the joys and pains of working in not for profit.
cons: People rise in this organization based on their compassion and personality, not on their abilty to do their jobs effectively.

pros: The United Way is a wonderful organization and does so much good for the community.  My role there was to run the annual campaign and do community presentations about giving, volunteering and advocating to benefit those less fortunate than us in society.
cons: Due to the cyclical nature of the annual campaign and our recent economic downturn it is very difficult to do long range planning with the United Way.

pros: Several friendly coworkers who care about what they do. The company provides bottles of water. Different departments host the monthly staff meetings, so nice change of pace. Some supervisors will accommodate occasional schedule changes.
cons: There has been a lot of contraction, the non-profit lost over $400,000 from 2013-2014, and the current outlook is pretty bleak. There's little job security, high turnover and below-average pay. You're responsible for cleaning. Lack of communication/cooperation between departments and management tended to be very slow in returning calls/emails, i.e. 3 weeks. Some unprofessionalism, seemed to struggle to organize, some managers do not care about the org's mission. Employees don't get much input.

pros: The opportunity to bring together private and public sector to tackle some of the most challenging social issues in Dane County fosters collaboration and ownership. Therefore, Opportunities for networking for a greater purpose are priceless.
cons: It is about who you know. There is some feeling of entitlement and arrogance across the organization. It is also way too political.

pros: The staff is small, so if you enjoy knowing everyone in the office this is a great size. Work hours are very flexible--HR is awesome. Workload is reasonable/moderate, but can feel mind-numbing.
cons: Office politics dominate almost everything you do. Some departments are better than others at encouraging employee development and creativity. Corporate feel in a non-profit world.

job_title: Development Executive in San Diego, CA
pros: Fun culture, lots of responsibility, flexibility, good vacation time and holidays, doing good, innovative work for the community/being a part of large-scale change, great way to understand business landscape in San Diego
cons: Because it is a nonprofit, you can expect a nonprofit salary. There is not a ton of room for growth; heavy workloads;

review_title: Okay for a first time job - not a long term role
job_title: Director of Community Impact in Gainesville, FL
pros:
- Challenging and fulfilling work
- Flexible work schedule and work/life balance
- Great opportunities and ever-evolving roles
cons:
- Pay is fairly low, higher than most nonprofits
- Poor management/leadership, inexperienced staff
- Nonprofits can attract some very bizarre and sometimes toxic staff members

pros: They have an excellent location in downtown San Francisco near BART and lots of food choices. Right across the street from the transbay bus.
cons: I observed a lot of turnover as well as not enough transparency around mission, vision and goals. Senior management hiring choices were questionable.

pros: Family oriented and friendly workplace, the chance to help people in need, the chance to volunteer, great place for a start up career.
cons: Not able to move up the ladder, Salaries are low because its a non profit organization, Upper management needs to follow thru on their promises.

pros:
Helps improve interpersonal and public speaking skills
Hands on with company representatives
The Staff is kind and cares about their employees 
Hands on with the agencies making a difference within our community
cons: Humble pay but it's a non-profit business so it is rewarding knowing you are helping the community

pros: I had a wonderful experience with United Way's North Shore AmeriCorps Program. The leadership was very supportive and provided strong oversight for the program. My placement provided a fantastic opportunity to develop teaching skills, and I will benefit from the relationships I built this year.
cons: The stipend is enough to live on but not higher. It's important to understand that it is truly a year of service before applying for this position.

review_title: Committed Nonprofit Organization, great place to grow your career
job_title: Program Director in Santa Cruz, CA
pros:
-Local approach with a National reach
-Small company size provided a tight knit team of supportive employees
cons:
- As with any nonprofit there were fluctuations in funding which can be deleterious to the programs that are supportive for the communities we are serving. 
- Legacy fundraising model in transition, comes with inherent issues.

review_title: Too many chiefs and not enough indians
pros: The work is meaningful and rewarding.  The brand is well known, but also a double-edge sword.  Either prospective donors LOVE United Way or Hate it!  The national compensation scandal a few years ago is still remembered.
cons: This United Way has too many six-figure salaried executives.

review_title: Company truly values its employees' contributions
pros:
-Great people
-Laidback and friendly atmosphere
-Excellent work/life balance
-Welcoming of creativity and innovation
cons: -Since it's a non-profit, it is lower paying and may not have the best employee benefits

pros:
Genuinely kind hearted people that know the difference they are making in their community and are motivated by it. 
Monthly staff meetings, bring together all sectors of the organization. 
Overall, a very well oiled machine.
cons: Nothing major from the time I spent there. One thing I would say is that there is a divide between the different departments but that's to be expected in such a large company.

pros: Great mission, good pay and benefits for non-profit, moving toward a Lean Six Sigma environment so working on improving processes
cons: Leadership can be really out of touch and don't always listen to the people on the ground; good deal of tension between departments

review_title: I generally had a positive learning and working experience at United Way of Greater Atlanta.
pros: United Way of Greater Atlanta is a great stepping-stone, since it is one of the largest human service agencies in the country.
cons: There is a lack of cohesiveness within the organization. Greater integration between departments could be beneficial.

pros: I worked with some amazing people and made some great connections . United Way was the best place I've ever worked. I was able to take on projects and learn a lot
cons: Campaign can be a little disorganized and last minute . Some organizations are still going by an old model for raising funds and need to be a little more innovative

review_title: Not enough pay for amount of responsibility
pros:
The feeling of helping others compared to working for a public sector organization is very rewarding. 
There benefits are fantastic.
cons:
You start to realize that there is a major focus on making money as a 'non-profit' but it seems as though this is mostly so that the senior staff can make their huge salaries.
My position did not pay nearly enough as it should've, even for today's economy.

review_title: Great place for networking with tons of agencies and businesses!
job_title: Senior Program Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Good reputation in community. Opens doors to lots of new connections. Very flexible work environment in some departments but not all. Summer hours are great!
cons: Sometimes feels like we get so caught up in strategy, planning and meetings that we forget what the work truly means. Too many internal meetings.

pros: Served on Advisory Board for UWCC-MLN - great organization and great group of agencies it supports.  Volunteers play an important role in supporting and advocating for meeting the needs of those less fortunate in the LKN region and making sure our mostly affluent communities do not overlook those most in need in our towns.
cons: None really, but could use more connection to main office in Charlotte for community assessments

pros: United Ways hire a LOT of people - you too can get a start in nonprofit work - and it's big enough that there's room for advancement. Of course everyone who works there has their heart in the right place.
cons: There is deep confusion about what they're trying to accomplish and how to do that.

pros: Great way to network with other nonprofits and some volunteer opportunities.
cons: Organization in desperate need of experienced, forward-thinking leadership. Little communication between CEO and staff, and between staff themselves. Campaign/fundraising always trumps community outreach efforts. Staff are micromanaged and not empowered to do their jobs. High stress, low pay. Overall toxic work environment made worse by no opportunities for advancement, no professional development, extremely limited resources and inefficient work space and technology.

pros:
- good benefits
- some good and caring people (like anywhere)
- good location
cons:
- hierarchical 
- poor salaries (when compared to other local nonprofits and cost of living) 
- hard to move up or around 
- poor HR service 
- culture required major changes at time of departure

pros: Great atmosphere. Good people, great cause. Overall supportive team. Great benefits and compensation. Working at United Way strengths your resume within the non profit sector. Excellent competent team.
cons:
There are jaded people that just send some negativity around. Not terrible but annoying.
It's a bit top down on management structure. Can be very stressful during busy time.

pros: Everyone at united way was so great to work with. I have nothing bad to say about the place at all. If you're working there for the right reasons you will love it.
cons: The salary can be low but it all depends on what youre looking for.

job_title: Project Manager in San Diego, CA
pros: Great work environment and wonderful people. The work we are trying to do is important and I feel attached to a larger mission.
cons: Nothing that affects my job, but there has been significant staff turnover for the last year. Board of directors made a change in executive leadership, which should change the dynamic for upper management.

pros: I love what United Way stands for and the people that work here believe in the organization's mission. Like any non-profit, it's all hands on deck to make things happen and it takes a great team to do just that.
cons: As a young professional I experienced a generational gap between me and other older employees. Some times it was hard to convey my innovative ideas to others.

review_title: Organization on a downward trajectory for several years.
pros:
Most employees are nice people, want to do a good job.
Meet our mission in some areas, funding and providing services to people in the community.
cons:
Senior management not up to the job.
Organization has not updated itself to reflect the changes in the market and economy that are affecting us.
Problems with fundraising and resource development, some are due to the down economy but it seems like other nonprofits are doing well or expanding when we're not.

job_title: Loaned Executive in San Antonio, TX
pros: Flexibility in schedule. Staff is amazing, and everyone loves working there. Lots of fun events, fundraisers, and they have speakers come in from all the local NPO's.
cons: Pay isn't so great. Can be demanding sometimes, including weekends and late nights. Hard to obtain a job, unless hired as an intern.

pros: Worth it for those starting out- good program management experience and exposure to many community orgs in the field.
cons: Pay is pretty low - be prepared to move on with what you learn. Tends to have too much internal politics/gossip. Senior staff can be vindictive and HR protects them.

pros: If you are talented and willing to learn, sociable, but also able to work independently, you will do very well here. Great team work, management works hard to communicate and be transparent- (No company is perfect)
cons: It is a non profit so the work is great, the pay is sufficient.   Work/life balance is mostly up to you.

review_title: If you want to grow professionally....this is not the place for you!
pros:
Office is spacious

Office is located in a convenient location  

Free parking
cons:
Staff members are not appreciated for the work they do

No Summer Hours

Cannot listen to music in the office

Staff members cannot be friends

No professional development/training

No opportunities to advance in career

Upper management micromanages everything 

No flexibility with work hours 

Lunch can ONLY be taken between the hours of 12pm and 2pm

pros: The atmosphere is very good for entry level professionals looking to develop their skills. The employees at Lake Area United Way are all very friendly and genuinely want to help each other succeed. I wasn't afraid to ask questions about the various responsibilities I had, which made for a comfortable environment to learn.
cons: If you're looking for a fast paced working environment, then this is not the company for you.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Benefits rock!
Passionate employees
Talented teams
Does more with less
cons:
Not agile - antiquated policies
Leaders play favorites - in terms of raises and bonuses
loyal employees not valued/not listened
Employee Culture Survey one sided
Mgmnt cannot seem to hold each other accountable

pros:
Great benefits, nice work environment, half day Fridays during the summer.

The mission and vision of the organization are clear and there's a lot to get behind there.
cons: There's always more work than can be done in any given week. While there's a focus on work/life balance sometimes that can be blurry.

review_title: Communications Director at local level pleased with the organiztaion
pros: strong support from the national UW to the local UW assisting in strong brand recognition. Mgmt supportive of personal needs. Ability to work on many various projects with many different agencies.
cons: everyone must fundraise. long hours during campaign season.

pros: Make a difference while doing good in your community. See the impact of your job every day. Like getting paid to volunteer.
cons: No defined career paths. Hard to get promotions. Top down management styles. Employee ideas not valued. Lack of cohesion amongst the different teams.

review_title: It was a good place to work.
pros:
My coworkers were kind and hardworking people.
I felt that working there gave me a chance to make a real difference in the lives of others.
Management took time out to mentor me.
cons:
I sometimes did not have enough to do.  
I felt that the pay was not great.
There was not a lot of hope of making a career there.

pros: Co-workers in other departments were amazing.  Generous, polite, helpful and always willing to help out in any capacity.
cons: Management refused to offer training to sub-ordinate but always faulted employee for not knowing particular programs to complete assignments.

pros: By working there you get the opportunity to do great work in the community and meet really important business leaders.
cons: It is very difficult to move up in the organization because of office politics. Leadership seems to be fond of particular individuals which stifles other employees.

pros: Great brand with demonstrated success.  On local level, the compensation structure is out of date and inconsistent.  Benefits are great!
cons: Too top heavy.  A few people make big bucks at the top, but middle management and below are not compensated competitively.  No room for career growth until someone retires.

pros: Working for United Way enabled for me to expand my horizons and connect with the community of Isabella County. Overall, it was a pleasure working with the team and I would recommend working with this non-profit organization to anyone.
cons: The only negative that comes to mind is that the internship did not directly translate to a full-time position with the organization.

review_title: Great compensations and benefits for non-profits!
pros: I used to work for community agencies then jumped to united way, I would say united ways compensation is without a doubt best of the best among non profits!
cons: Sometimes I felt like we're just a middle man - we raise fund and partner agencies delivere work with larger workload and lower pay

pros: Great mission, benefits, opportunities to continue education, nice vacation package, good retirement and pension, fun environment, strong brand
cons: Hard to fundraise in today's climate. Off hour events. Long hours during campaign season. Too many meetings in the culture.

pros: The organization genuinely wants to improve the communities it serves. There are also some great people that work there.
cons: There is a lack of opportunity to grow professionally or advance. Salaries are skewed significantly- to the point where full time employees have trouble feeding their families or paying bills. The organization is not forward thinking.

review_title: Fund raising and Community Awareness is what I do
job_title: President/Chief Executive Officer in Hobbs, NM
pros: United Way provides great resources specific to each community on what are the true needs and we are best able to do meaningful work.
cons: People dont always understand what United Way does or why it exists

pros:
Friendly, supportive work environment
Collaborative work teams
Effective and comprehensive systems (CRM, Outlook, Intranet)
Respectful co-workers
Everyone treated as equals
cons:
Forced time off due to budgetary constraints
Time management not always the greatest, resulting in some rushes to prepare for events

pros: United Way Worldwide (formerly United Way of America) is a place with terrific co-workers who possess tremendous drive and idealism.
cons: While at United Way Worldwide, it seemed quite obvious to all that there is little room for advancement within the organization.

pros: Meaningful work. It is great to know that you are making a difference. Very flexible. Great people. It is a fabulous place to work - it is very rare to have a case of the "Monday Blues."
cons: As a non-profit organization with a low cost per dollar raised, resources are limited. Budgets are tight. Salaries are not competitive with the for profit sector.

review_title: The mission is clear and most employees want to make a difference.
pros:
Great coworkers 
Passionate about helping the community 
Flexible schedule
cons: So much to be done with not enough staff.  One person often does the work of 2-3 people.  Unexpected meetings and unexpected deadlines make the work day feel like an emergency at times.

review_title: More power-seeking managers than you'd expect at an org that's supposed to be supporting the community
job_title: Project Manager in North Indianapolis, IN
pros: Some good people inside teams, can feel good about mission. Fancy new office.
cons: A lot of power (and money) concentrated at the top. Individual contributors matter very little. Employees are discouraged from having differing opinions from leadership. Lots of turnover.

review_title: Poor structure/do not value employees/supervisor's leaderships skills are horrible
pros: Learned a lot, networked with a lot of people within and outside of the organization. Good medical benefits and 401k. Great Opportunities for growth
cons:
TURN OVER GALORE! There is def no work/ life balance. You are pretty much sucked in working all the time. Aside from the typical 8-12 hour days. You go home and all you think of is the billion things you need to keep working on, checking emails, getting and making calls after work hours.. working here becomes your life and it can destroy your personal life.

There is a HUGE lack of structure. You are pushed to donate to the organization when salaries for the most part are very low  especially for the long hours you are expected to work. There is no merit raise, you only receive a 2%  cost of living annual raise and if you work as a teacher or demo school staff you get ZERO. You have to learn on the fly with little to no direction and when mistakes are made you get chewed out but when you do your job or you feel you excel you get ZERO recognition. There is a huge lack of leadership, direction and motivation from some of the VPs. I  personally received very little direction, worked like crazy  with no raise, and would be constantly put down in front of other coworkers by my supervisor. Yet, I lived and breathed to always do my best. I would get home after working 10-12 hours to  continue checking on emails, working on whatever I needed to and always thinking on ways to improve the work I was doing... this represents ZERO work/life balance.

pros: An Excited and energetic staff made work enjoyable everyday from start to finish. It was very rewarding to see the difference you were making in the community and individuals lives.
cons: Some of the upper management could use some more real world business experience. Most all decisions that were made needed to be run through upper management which caused delays in progress.

job_title: Development Associate in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: Great mission alongsode great people. Always a purpose to showing up to work, and great impact on the community and schools.
cons: No real major cons. It is nonprofit work, and a well-run organization. I have to out a certain number of words.

pros:
helping the community through summer lunch program for kids.
many locations served, provided a safe and positive atmosphere for children
cons: quality of food was sub par at some locations.  had some complaints about not having many options, low quality of ingredients and so on

review_title: a great place to work if you can keep up with the rapid pace
pros: treats employees with respect, shows appreciation by recognizing their accomplishments, keeps them 'in the loop' with regard to company activities, employees have a sense of being a part of something bigger than themselves
cons: discourages telecommuting, long hours, health insurance coverage could be more extensive, fitness center could be better

pros: Good place to work if you want the experience of working at a nonprofit and getting a taste of all nonprofits
cons: Highly competitive but that is to be expected.  You will be required to do a lot and you will be expected to deliver

review_title: Wonderful for a potpourri non-profit experience
pros: opportunity to speak with many community organizations and understand health and human service work on the ground; cross-sector cutting work between nonprofit, gov and private sector
cons: Frequent change in guiding principles and mission make it a challenging work environment especially on the development end of things

pros: United Way has a good mission in empowering people to participate in their families and community. The organization has targeted areas of service which gives it more focus than it had traditionally.
cons: Like in many nonprofits, if you want to earn a big salary you shouldn't be working here. Nonprofits need to keep overhead low so donated funds go to services.

review_title: One of the best and most rewarding jobs I've had.  Great start to a fundraising and nonprofit career.
pros: Working with high level CEOs and Community Leaders.  Great way to learn basic fundraising and program management skills.
cons: Significant burn-out.  Role becomes redundant after a few campaign seasons.

pros: People are very smart and passionate. Made some lifelong friends. Learned a great deal, had fun, and made an impact.
cons: CEO needs to go. Lacks passion, is vindictive, petty and egotistical. Expects Senior management to duke it out. No consensus decision making. The emperor has no clothes, but is surrounded by yes men and women.

pros: Nothing but positive things to say about working with this organization.  Great team of people who work tirelessly for a great cause.
cons: The only "con" would be that which is true for most human-service, not-for-profiit organizations, the pay is not comparable to your counterparts in corporate America.

pros:
Decent salary + benefits
Great coworkers
Generally good, pleasant people, including leadership team

Horrible leadership
Terrible communication
Fast turnover without explanation

Very low morale among staff
Leadership unwilling to accept suggestions to improve situation

review_title: Very high turnover.  Losing accounts constantly.
job_title: Campaign Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Management tries very hard to continue motivating but an uphill battle.
cons: Highest turnover I have ever seen at a company. Losing accounts daily due to antiquated old school practices. Poor communication, little support. Still doing the 3 part payroll deduction forms from 20+ years ago. No one wants to be bothered with something that cumbersome.

pros: United Way is a great place to work. There is a great deal of professionalism in the workplace, and everyone is very welcoming. Leadership is very committed to helping people develop their skills.
cons: There is a lot of bureaucracy masked as "teamwork." You have to get everyone's input on projects that don't necessarily impact everyone.

review_title: Important mission, treat employees well, good work life balance.
pros: Benefits, mission and networking opportunities are good. Not a high level of stress on a day to day basis. Convenient parking. Supports volunteerism on a regular basis outside the office.
cons: Outdated systems and org structure, poor management at VP levels.    Unclear accountabilities results in decision-making by committee on everything. Level of professionalism often lacking

pros: The staff is welcoming and kind. You can tell that leaders are incredibly passionate about the work they do in the community.
cons: When I started at United Way there seemed to be a rift between upper management and lower levels. In the last few months that I worked there it seemed to improve but there was incredibly high turnover while I was there.

review_title: Empassioned coworkers and many community needs that we addressed.
pros: Great teammates, computer network support, marketing materials and mission.  Good resources to support the work.
cons: Management - flavor of the month with supervisors; had 7 supervisors (sometimes two at the same time!) in only 4 years there.

pros: Its nice to give back to the community
cons: Personal interests influence granting making decisions and Supervisors who are not The Supervisor of evaluation had no prior training in evaluation and was biased to pleasing her senior management team.

review_title: UW provided a lot of exposure to many local non-profits.
pros: Great opportunity to give back to your community. Great Benefits and very rewarding. The community projects were a lot of fun.
cons: There are Politics like every company. If you give your best everyday, you hope that good things happen to you. It's a Corporate environment although non-profit.

pros: Awesome people, flexible hours, decent area, easy to get to, near by places to eat on lunch break awesome awesome awesome
cons: Parking is a hassle when big meetings are taking place, a couple of rude co-workers. Nosy co workers, people will eat your food out of the refrigerator.

pros: Health benefits, decent PTO, retirement plan with small match.
cons: Low pay, work culture isn’t always productive or professionally  focused

pros: Mission, well-intended staff, community impact, community connections
cons: Inconsistent leadership, nepotism/cronyism. Management and culture is too rigid, stagnant. Need to focus more on professional/career development.  Insufficient investment in infrasructure (IT, systems).

pros: Great work-life balance is the best part of the job. Working at UWMC also allows you to meet a lot of great people and participate in various community/volunteer/networking activities with people from all over chicago
cons: Direction from leadership very unclear, turnover is atrocious. little/no training. No talent development, very little opportunity for advancement. 9 CEO's in the last 27 years.

pros: Great community involvement and connectedness, fantastic co-workers, great learning experiences, challenging and rewarding.
cons: It is challenging to make ends meet with the salary; a second job is not feasible due to the time requirements for certain meetings.

job_title: Information and Referral Specialist in Orlando, FL

cons: High Stress work since I handle calls from crisis, suicide, and financially distressed clients.  However, if ever you feel stressed they are always encouraging employees to take a moment for themselves.

Don't know if the Board doesn;t care or is unaware that they are losing staff an average of 2-3 per MONTH. cons: Unexpectedly high turnover for being a great place to work.

pros: A very respected organization with a meaningful agenda and concrete action plans. The workplace is very diverse and effectively uses that diversity to its advantage.

pros: Been around awhile with lots of local connections.  It's a good place to get experience and use those connections to get a better paying job.

Non-profit is very rewarding but the pay is sometimes hard to swallow.

When I started everyone was quick to include me in everything and I felt like I gained 15 friends
